content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
TL:DR? See ConclusionINTRODUCTION:An old game (by the time I wrote this review) but a great game nonetheless.As you might know, this is a Star Wars game based on the Clone Wars era where you are the leader of an elite Clone Commando Unit tasked with some of the most dangerous and most critical missions in service of the Galactic Republic.PROS:+ Story: -Amazing story that places you not in the eyes of a skillful Jedi or a powerful Sith, but in the boots of Clone Troopers fighting the war. The game delivers in terms of story with its superior voice acting by Temuera Morrison (Jango Fett) as well and the various personalities of your squad mates really adds to the experience.+ Squad Mechanics: -You cannot Rambo (go solo) this game, mainly because the squad is mandatory, BUT also because the game is brutal as hell (like most old FPS games). Enemies are really hard to kill without your squad's support requiring the players to properly order their squads into position and direct their fire when necessary.+ Graphically pleasing despite its age: -Released on 2005, this game carries a dated visual design, but pleasing nonetheless. Animation is good and the atmosphere is immersive. (I simply love the HUD in this game)+ Sound: -One of the greatest OST I have ever heard. (Vode An is the greatest of these OST)+ Gameplay: -Lengthy campaign without getting boring: There is always action around the corner.CONS:- Squad AI is a bit limited: -Although the AI, for the most part, is intelligent and is far more useful than some of the other AI partners in modern games, I feel as though a bit more could have been done. They follow command well enough.- Bugged Graphic setting in terms of Bump Mapping: -Remained unfix to this day. (can be turned off in the options menu though)Additional Note:The game is linear (corridor shooting), from start to finish. THIS IS NOT A BAD THING PEOPLE. Not all games need to be open world, specially if the game, such as this one, is trying to properly tell the story in a progressive fashion giving the player a sense of direction and purpose.CONCLUSION:MUST BUY and MUST OWN for any Star Wars fan or First Person Shooter fans.--------------------------------------------------------- Like my Reviews? Follow my Curator's Page:Miyumi's Review Corner (MIRECO)

content:
Posted: February 11, 2015
												People often complain about the stone-faced, bald and monotomous space marines in videogames; how they're an extremely overused template and stifle the development of round characters. Republic Commando puts an interesting spin on this complaint: It gives you four clones; four space marines. That's where the complaining ends.Republic Commando is a squad based shooter set in the Star Wars universe during the Clone Wars. You play Delta 38 "Boss", leader of a highly specialised and extremely elite squad of Clones. You're bred with a great affinity for your clone bretheren. Your squad is as much a part of your arsenal as your special rifles and armour. Repulic Commando translates this premise to gameplay in an absolutely incredible way. You can 'direct' your squad to perform tasks while you hold off the enemy. Or you can work on the objective while you let them hold the line. The surprise in this comes from their intelligence. More often than not, CPU allies are less than helpful. Not the Clone Commandos; they are in a league of their own. They take, and move through cover, hide when the odds are against them, secure the area before helping you instead of running in headlong, and their aim is about as good as your own, so they don't feel considerably overpowered. What also helps is a careful balance of enemies. There are just enough in each room to keep it interesting, but never too many to make it feel like a grindfest. Your three squadmates (and yourself) are the bread and butter of the game's presentation. 2005 graphics haven't aged so dignified, but the artstyle gets the job done. Everything looks slightly grittier and messier than it does in the films. You'll quickly determine this when you use the melee button a droid for the first time and the grease and battery acid are wiped off your visor with a laser. The helmet display resembles that of Metroid Prime a lot, complete with ambient effects and splatter. But, enough about the visuals, the real fun is in the sound. You, and your brothers engage in a lot comic banter to keep spirits up. You, the boss are the tough as nails leader, voiced by Mr Jango Fett himself. Delta 62 "Scorch" is the squad's demolitions expert and all-round joker. Delta 40 "Fixer" is the straight man and computer specialist. And finally, Delta 07 "Sev", the sniper and gruesome sadist. The dialogue exchange is worth its weight in gold and because the game's pace is tight and condenced, they don't end up looping up. It gives the whole endeavor a lively character that is a nice offset to the gritty visuals. Still, there are some things you'll have to consider. The game isn't very long; you can tear through it an afternoon. Replaying it wastes some of the surprise moments, but you'll be better at some of the positioning and directions, allowing you to focus on speedrunning for instance. Some gauntlets can also feel extremely cheap at first. Sometimes you'll end up reloading a particular section over and over again because you squad gets wiped within the first 10 seconds. And then there is the ending off course. I'll let you figure that out on your own. I can reccommend this game to anyone who is a Star Wars fan, and to anyone looking for a shooter with exemplary squad AI and gameplay.

content:
Posted: October 1, 2014
												In this game, you play as Commando Delta 38 (Boss/Leader).The game follows the story of three missions throughout Delta Squad's career in the Separatist Crisis.From fighting alongside wookies to getting your face drilled by a scavenger droid, you lead your squad to complete objectives your normal, mass produced, counterparts could/cannot.The game and story is nice, I loved it and maybe you will too. This is from the soldier's perspective as to the usual jedi perspective. The game plays pretty damn smooth on PC. I haven't had any real game-breaking problems. The game is old enough to even play on lower-end laptops. You get to actually order your squad to do things (ex.When you issue the Search and Destroy order, they become aggressive and move ahead even if you're looking around, You can order them to set demolition charges on objectives to progress or you could order them to secure the area and plant the demolition charge yourself. You can even send them to sniper/anti-armor positions as well as turrets.)If you lose all your health, you get downed and the game doesn't end until your entire squad is downed. So while you're downed you could either tell them to maintain current orders (ex. search and destroy) or order the closest squad member to revive you. There's also the option to load the last save while you're downed. There's also quicksaves, I hotkeyed mine to F1 and F3 because I can screw things up a lot. I don't think you can really get through this game without ordering your squad around. You take quite a bit of damage, even on medium difficulty. Just for future reference, don't run infront of your squad while they're firing a sniper or a anti-armor grenade. Bad things happen. . .All in all this game was great for it's time and pretty short if you know what you're doing. I just REALLY wish there was a sequal just because of the ending. . .

number of helpful: 347 of 352 people (99%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 2, 2014
												The moment you boot up Republic Commando is the moment your realize this isn't your usual Star Wars games.Presented in a darker, militaristic tone, you're placed in the shoes of Boss, a freshly manufactured clone, whose the leader of a commando squad of four. The opening epitomizes the message of the game, that you're a soldier and you have to rely on your squad-mates- as a side-note, look up during the short scene on Kimino, that's the attention to detail this game has. The art-style is harsher and the droids have an threating growl to their voices (♥♥♥♥ those whiny voices Lucas went with). It certainly feels unique since it uses its own soundtrack instead of constantly using John Williams pieces as a crutch. Stylistically, the game is beautiful, with a absolutely rocking soundtrack that knows when to throw in those vocals and drum-beats. Graphically, it's a 2005 game and console port, at 60 fps and proper lighting it's better than the original xbox version for sure. However, I believe it's the art-style instead of the textures that carries the visual direction. The actual gameplay harkens back to Rainbow Six with how you use your AI partners to clear levels and focus fire. Some of my favorite aspects of the game are the fact that you can 'prep' for battle. You can order a sniper to sit back or have one of your guys bombard the enemy from grenadier nest. Now you can only do this through context sensitive actions, but it's more a feature of the level design that rewards player thought than a "you can only proceed after using a laser-designated airstrike on these helpless sand people".The AI is very compentent too. They will require revival, but that's only on the hardest sections of the game. I never felt like they were idiotic, and actually they keep up with you extremely well. It's no F.E.A.R, but for a squad-based shooter, the AI never failed me on the several play-throughs I've had both past and present.Augmenting this squad is your own weaponry. The standard blaster is honestly a peashooter to me, but you get a mother♥♥♥♥ing shotgun in a Star-wars game, and it is god-damn awesome. The standard blaster can be switched to both a sniper rifle and an anti-tank grenade launcher, allowing to have a total of four weapons (one weapon you can pick up from an enemy soldier) with three types of grenades. You also have a blade-fist, and like Halo, your melee attack is brutal and effective in close-combat. In total, you have a solution for every problem and ammo is given often enough to use all your tools while given sparingly enough to not go willy-nilly with sniper and rpg shots.This game has become one of my favorite Star Wars games mostly because of the characters and story. Your three squad-mates have plenty of memorable quips and though they were stereotypical in their personalities, they give that Star Wars flair that prevents the game from being a super grim-dark slog. I'd never consider them annoying and by the end of the game you really detect how the characters have become more brothers than comrades-at-arms.  Story-wise you get some background information on some of the Clone-war plot-lines from the Prequels. However you never have a moment where it overly masturbates over the prequels' storylines or characters, it plays it straight and the only time you ever see a truly iconic character from Star Wars is once. RC is it's own game and story inside the Star Wars universe and I really admire that. It doesn't need Han Solo or Luke Skywalker to be a Star Wars game. And the aforementioned moment actually comes as a real reward to an honestly disappointing ending. A pat on the back for working through the difficult sections of RC.However I have my misgivings with RC. For one it's short. Not any shorter than an average FPS campaign of today, but at the time it was a very short game. There are only a handful of worlds to go to. Although the finales end with a bang (the Republic Ghostship's final mission has the most badass ending setpiece I've ever seen in a Star Wars game), they aren't extremely varied. You're going to be inside military compounds with only a few examples having open level design (these often have squad-points where you can assign snipers and grenadiers). There will be a few stretches where you have to go down a narrow corridor. Fighting waves of enemies. Ho-humming your way along. It'd be an injustice if I didn't emphasis a 'few' though. Most often the game gives you options and some cool set-piece battles to command through.The game can also be back-breakingly hard at points. I like this, but sometimes you'll get super-bullet spongy enemies (the reason why the main blaster feels ♥♥♥♥♥♥) back to back. The super-battle droids are the worst offenders. We're talking fighting up to six of those ♥♥♥♥ers at once, in a bare-knuckled shoot-out. On harder difficulties, this can make the game undeniably frustrating. Which turns those glorious finales into a sweat-inducing curse-ridden rant.Also no sequel. When you finish this game, you will agree that it ends at the worst moment. It doesn't feel unfinished due to just how badass the ending finale is. I mean there's a stretch that basically deconstructs the entire premise of the game and makes you realize just how important your squad is. But story-wise, you'll have to read a book to ever see the end of the Republic Commando series. And honestly, the book was 'meh' like most video game books.The squad gameplay can be a bit disappointing at times. It's more arcadey than realistic, and sometimes the squadmates are there to just hide how bullet-spongy the enemies are. I'd have liked to be able to always have a guy with his sniper-rifle out rather than them having to setup. I'd also have liked to have the squad mates use grenades more often or engage in melee instead of using those aforementioned blasters. Asking them to switch to shotguns would've been the best damn thing too. But every complaint I have with the game ends with a 'however'. The squad gameplay can be meh, however the way the game uses the squad adds extreme weight to the narrative and tone. The story is abrupt, however it has so many moments in the game that have struck with me for a damn decade. The levels aren't varied, however they really give that "behind enemy lines blowing up their♥♥♥♥♥♥quot; feeling.For $10.00, you get a game that I would mention in the same breath as KotOR 1&2 and Jedi Outcast. It's not just a great Star Wars game, it's a game I would recommend to people that know nothing about the universe. It's a game I would play even if I wasn't in the mood for a Star Wars fix. This was a work of passion for the devs, who used Star Wars as a vehicle to tell a story of cooperation and brotherhood more through the gameplay than cutscenes.EDIT: Some things I forgot to mentioned or worded poorly. For one the AI of the squadmates is competent, but the enemy droids are as dumb as they are in the Prequels. Only the Super Battle Droid or Droideka pose any threat due to their bullet-spongey nature and their constantly attacking AI pattern. An enemy force you encounter later mixes things up, but their use of cover is only so effective and they do have a habit of mixing effective tactics with standing in the open.As a whole though, the enemy variety is noteworthy. Each major faction in the Clone Wars (as were present up to episode III) is represented and has units that are both cannon fodder and those that require squad focus fire. The enemy forces are gradually changed out and each world introducing a new faction that is better than the one before. Better armored, armed, and tactical. You'll never meet a force that can truly match your Commandos, but the array or melee and ranged enemies is remarkable for such a short game. Also, there is multiplayer in RC. Do I play it? Well, once or twice. It's a deathmatch arena game in the style of older shooters. Make of that what you will.

content:
Posted: May 4, 2015
Tl'dr version:  One of the best Star Wars games out there. To this day, an underrated and often overlooked part of the evolution of squad based shooters; also included is a fantastic soundtrack.Great, (for the most part) A.I, and likeable squad mates make this short, but engaging ride all the sweeterElaborated version: I often find that people have a tendency to harp on about SW: Battlefront and KOTOR a little bit too much. They were great games, (especially the latter) but I found them to be deeply flawed games. SW: Republic Commando, while flawed in some ways, manages to pull everything together in a much more satisfying way. This is obviously due to it's genre, and the nature of the mission structure. Not a thing is out of place. This comes at price however; the mission structure is disjointed to say the least, and the story is bare bones. However you'll get the feeling this was deliberate, as just like in real combat, and especially if you're a 'slightly less expendable' clone, you'll not be kept up to the date with the war as a whole. The game will take it tacitly that you know the Star Wars lore already and fling references to the films at you without guilt or trepidation. For a avid SW fan this wont be a problem, I unfortunately found myself lost at some points in the dialogue.  The mechanics are just as you expect from a Squad shooter; intuitive, tight, and easy to control. The PC version runs great with a M&C set up, but a controller is also possible. It might be necessary to have button mapping software however, as the games age breaks the controls. You squad mates don't need you to hold their hand, and can perform simple tasks without you needing to give the order. However, they will occasionally rush in a 'no win scenario' and be dropped in matter of seconds under a hail of plasma fire. This will happen to you over and over, and their really is no way to stop it happening. This does have the unintended use of keeping aggro off you, while you attend to other matters. The game features the modern invent system of the FPS. That is to say. You're limited to two normal weapons, 1 special weapon, and multiple attachments to your assault rifle, thus giving the weapon variety a much needed boost. There is a weapon for every scenario. Now, onto the soundtrack. As a avid collector of game Soundtracks, this would have a proud spot on my list. In short; it's fantastic. A mixture of choral, and star wars symphony tropes mixed together to create a chilling, but engaging and epic theme. Definitely worth getting on soundtrack.Finally, onto the negatives, and they are surprisingly few. The game is no looker, and is really showing it's age as of 2015. However, over a decade on and it's vista's are still rather eye catching, especially the later missions on Kashyyyk. Also, while I said the A.I was great; that was for last decade. Now not so much. Your squad mates will get stuck on geometry and regularly fail to revive you, even if their aren't any enemies in the area. This is all forgiven however by the amazing squad dynamic of banter that is constantly being thrown around. Very rarely will you actually care what your objective is, but you'll genuinely like and care for your squad as the game progresses, and you feel like this is a family. Final thoughts: By no means a looker, and to modern audiences this game might feel slightly lost in why this game was so great back in the day, however I still recommend giving it a try if it comes on sale. Everything is here:• Great Combat• Great Characters• Great Soundtrack• Reasonable length.*Be aware however, the MP for the game has been shut down.*

content:
Posted: July 19, 2013
												One of the better Star Wars games out there. I despise the prequel trilogy, yet I still found this game to be quite good. It's an FPS where you play as the leader of an elite squad of commandos sent on the toughest of jobs.You can position your squad members, each one is supposedly skilled at different tasks, and it's mostly just blasting your way through droids and bugs in caverns, facilities, and space ships. You get the typical weapons--shotguns, pistols, sniper, rifle, etc. mostly in star-wars-style laser blasting form. It's about ten hours long, and it's a pretty good campaign with some neat set-pieces. The squad members have some fun personalities and the voice work is solid. Since it's an older game, there are no iron sights, so that might be hard to get used to. The graphics hold up well, although I do believe it lacks widescreen. There are some compatibility issues, so you might need to take a look at the forums if you run into problems.

												On the timeline of great FPS games, Republic Commando sadly lurks in the shadow of the classics, but outdoes them in many respects. This Metroid Prime-inspired and slightly darker take on the Star Wars mythos puts you right in the shoes of a squad of covert Republic infiltrators carrying out a series of increasingly tense missions in tightly designed levels. A cohesive package of sound, graphics, and story that coalesce to form one of the ofter overlooked masterpieces of the genre.

content:
Posted: May 4, 2015
												EA, Disney, and LucasArts could quite literally make 100 million dollars by releasing a sequel for this game.Unfortunately, they're too busy releasing a washed out version of Battlefront.Updated 13.10.2015Like i thought, after playing the Battlefront Beta it's now clear that the game is absolute garbage. It's boring, cookie cutter shooter where you just spawn, run forward, kill everything you see and repeat. It might be "fun" for the first 30 minutes but after that you'll probably get bored and move to some other more mechanically interesting title. There are also dramatically less features than in the original two games, it was also announced today that they are going to be releasing a 50€ Season Pass for the game which will provide early access to future content for buyers etc.Now, business practices like this are terrible for the gaming industry. There is absolutely no way you can defend it without sounding like a sheep. Then again, i probably wouldn't be too♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥about it if they actually released even half of the content that was already introduced in the Battlefront games more than 10 years ago.So, getting back to Republic Commando. It's still a great game, instead of buying Battlefront get this game instead. You certainly won't waste your money that way.

												No nonserious review this time, I can't think of anything.And here's my little info thing. Star Wars: Republic Commando is a tactical first-person shooter taking place in the prequel trilogy, or the Rise of the Empire Era, during a period of three to four years known as The Clone Wars, which is infact, my favorite part of Star Wars. Yes, get mad at me for liking the prequels. You play as Boss, a clone commando who leads Delta Squad, a squad of commandoes. There is Scorch, the explosives expert, Fixer, what you could call a hacker I guess, and Sev, the sniper.Time for the review part.Pros:+ First off, THE MUSIC. It's amazing!+ The graphics are quite good.+ The gameplay is decent, better than some other first person shooters.+ It has a good storyline, even though it's short. + Good voice acting+The characters are good. Cons:- Widescreen support has to be edited in.- Campaign is short.- Cliffhanger ending.Star Wars fan? Pick it up!Get's a 9/10 from me!

number of helpful: 73 of 75 people (97%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												I remember playing this game way back on the original Xbox. It's not through rose-colored glasses that I say this is the greatest squad-based shooter I've ever played.Let's start with the atmosphere. It's spot on. Any casual Star Wars fan will recognize most of the enemies and locations. The level and character designs are grittier than what you see in the movies, and that fits the tone perfectly. The HUD is one of the best I've ever seen, because YOU SEE THE BORDERS OF YOUR HELMET! Such a simple design choice affects your immersion immensely.So everything around you is cool. What about the combat? This game FEELS great. The modular weapons system is genius.  The squad commands are easy to learn but hard to master. The difficulty is pleasantly challenging; don't expect yourself to be repeating tons of levels, but do expect to be constantly searching for health and ammo. The weapons feel rewarding to use, and above all, the squad-based combat is amazing. You FEEL bad♥♥♥♥♥ You FEEL like it's you four protagonists against the world. And you WANT to take 'em all on.Your three Clone Commando compatriots, Scorch, Fixer, and Sev, are exceptional AI companions (especially for 2005). They are effective in combat, respond to commands instantly, and generally don't make the kind of dumb decisions that make you rage at AI companions. They don't talk much, but you can still feel personality emanating from them.On the note of character, the one category where this game falters is story. You know where you are, and you know why. You have objectives. But that's about it. The characters don't change over time. There are no plot twists. There is an instance of tragic loss (I won't spoil it for you), and it hits you hard. But there is room for improvement in that area.Besides the story, what other improvements could be made? I won't comment on the graphics, because this game is coming up on 10 years old, but I will say they've aged well. The only thing that springs to mind is the level design. Don't get me wrong, the levels are designed fine, but it gives away what's to come. When you see a spot where you can issue a sniping command, you know there's enemies directly ahead. Health and ammo are always located directly behind large groups of enemies. It's textbook old-fashioned level design, but you always know what's coming.One final point: because this is an older game, a 1920x1080 aspect ratio is not an option it offers. It's a minor detail, but an important one.In conclusion, ten years later, this is still an incredible game. Although the story is never going to be a selling point, everything else about this game is great. It feels like you're taking a first-person trip through the summer action film spectacular that Star Wars never had. I highly recommend it to anyone who puts gameplay ahead of graphics. Amongst the vast troves of LucasArts treasures, this gem certainly shines bright.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2015
												Yes, the first few missions may be dull: Slice this, snipe that and so on. But that isn't the point. The point is, you need to work as a team. Sure, I may be a Star Wars fan myself but this doesn't affect my opinion on this fantasic game. To the people who say the graphics make up the game entirely, just do yourself a favour and don't play a single game for the rest of your life. Sure, the graphics in this game aren't up to scratch with today's standards but they sure were back in the good days of 2005. To be honest, I think they're great! The gameplay and story line is simply amazing. It brings you back to Geonosis, Kashyyk, an abandoned Republic Cruiser and a few other places. I don't think there is another Commando game out there that is based on Star Wars. But if there is, this has got to be one of the best around. I spent heaps of time playing Star Wars Battlefront 1 & 2 and let me tell you, those are amazing games too. The squad that you play with is also very responsive and helpful (unlike in many other games). They'll do what you tell them to do. No questions asked. Unless they are under heavy fire and it is protocol-wise required to defeat the enemy first (goddammit just revive me already haha). Scorch really does keep the squad alive with his 'jokes', athough he can say it the wrong times.But too bad Lucas Arts and Pandemic have left the Star Wars games, they were doing a fantastic job. Anyway, overall this is a fantastic game and I hope it won't be forgotten. If you are looking for a multiplayer, try going to Star Wars Battlefront 2. That is also an amazing game. I'll give it 9.5/10. Buy it already if you haven't! Have fun! :)

												Don't let my hours fool you, I've completed this game nearly 3 times over. This game is frankly one of the greatest Star Wars games out there. Republic Commando puts you in the boots of (you guessed it) a clone commando, with 3 squadmates. You travel to locations like Geonosis, Kashyyyk, and an abandoned Republic ship. This game focuses on squadwork, while you or another squadmate is arming a charge to get into a locked door, the other 3 are stopping the super battle droid shooting at you (which are actually kinda intimidating in this game). This is an older game, but you will still be impressed with the graphics to a degree, and at the not-as-expensive-as-98%-of-all-fps-shooters-out-there price of $10, I believe that this quality game is well worth your money!

												So, ive been a gamer all my life especially with FPS games, I started with halo in 2000, and moved to Call of duty, with the occasional Battlfield, in all my 20 YEARS of gaming, there has been no other first person shooter that has touched me the same way PERIOD. The story is compelling, deep and emotional having you go through real struggles. The gameplay is fluid, and smooth, better than any other first person shooter, and ive played : Halo 1 through 4, Call of duty : 1 through 4 Modern warfare 1 through 3 Battlefield 1942, 2142, battlefield 2, 3. This game TRUMPS THEM ALL. Commanding the commandos is easy to understand and simple without interrupting the gameplay flow. The amount of weapons is a comfortable amount that give you versatility without bogging you down. The commandos are like real people with thier commentary and feedback! Its also actually difficult, you dont regenerate health, the enemies are harder but not unfair, you dont get unrealistic amounts of ammo, and the scenarios are down to earth and feel like solid military situations that could come up. I cant rate this game high enough it holds the top 3 star wars games ive ever played. P.S its not 3rd i just couldnt pick a number 1 haha. Please do yourself a favor and buy this game you wont regret it.

number of helpful: 28 of 29 people (97%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												For coming out in 2005 this game still is a thrill to go back and relive the ultimate Clone Special Ops experience. You will be tasked with dealing with the most elite and discreet Republic operations, and leading a group of 4 (including yourself) elite Clone soldiers called Commandos. To begin, the gameplay is really good for a 2005 game. The shooting action gets really intense in the latter part of the game, and you will have to learn how to manage your squads survival as well as your own. Get too caught up in keeping your squad fit, and your own health will fall and you will go unconscious. Focus too much on your own health and equipment, and your squad will be left without orders and ultimately end up dying. This ends up being a gameplay goal for you as you must balance the two in order to have a successful playthrough (unless you want to play on the easiest difficulty). Although this does end up becoming a problem when your squad completely goes against their own common sense and runs out into a crowd of a bunch of droids, guns blazing, and gets shot down within seconds. Your squad also tends to run in front of you as you're throwing a grenade, which is super annoying because it will take down your shields and your health, as well as your squad member's, and you will still have enemies firing at you. I also feel the game is a little bit too difficult as you will find yourself screaming at your monitor on the Normal difficulty setting. Perhaps the developers could have balanced the difficulties by adding a fourth one (easy would still be easy, add a normal, normal would be hard, and hard would be very hard). But still, the game is still enjoyable despite the setbacks of a few gameplay issues. The guns are also nice. Most of them have decent sounds (other ones being laughable), and they have a good difference in purpose and power. The grenades, with the exception of the flash-bang grenade, are all pretty useful. Although none stand out above the other in the department of usefulness as they're all pretty much the same: aim at your enemy and throw. But still, they're a decent touch.The presentation is at an average level. With your standard graphics card you can max this game out, and the visuals won't look too bad. The textures are decent, and you won't really see any frame rate drop or texture pop-ins. The game overall has excellent environments that all differ from each other drastically. You'll go from fighting on the sandy and rocky world of Geonosis to the "abandoned" Republic ship in a matter of hours. With the varied environments and average graphics with no presentation technical difficulties, I can confidentially saw this game has above par presentation given its age.Now, onto the fun part, the content of Star Wars Republic Commando. First off, the story is really good. You are placed in command of Delta Squad, an elite group of Republic Commandos, which essentially are just Clone super soldiers. You will be given a variety of missions ranging from destroying a Droid Factory to helping the leader of the Wookies on Kashyyyk. Along the way you will unlock a few extras, which aren't really anything special, but they're a decent addition. The game is honestly too short. With the edition of another planet this game would have easily felt more complete. But the content that is there is fun and replayable, so it doesn't diminish the game too much. The multiplayer is remotely enjoyable, but will get old quickly. The community is either dead silent or a bunch of snotty veterans who trash talk new players and exploit the more powerful weapons. The maps themselves aren't anything out of the box, and quite bland, which is a shame considering the variety and design of the campaign maps were quite well. You'll most likely end up playing the campaign 1 or 2 times and maybe the multiplayer an hour or two (unless you find the multiplayer really fun, which I doubt most will).All in all I can say this game was a very good addition to the Star Wars franchise. Although it is a little short and has some gameplay issues and a below par multiplayer, you will find yourself thoroughly enjoying the amazing campaign and its awesome storytelling, environments, and characters. For the current price of $9.99 you should definitely pick this game up and relive or enjoy for the first time one of the greatest Star Wars gaming experiences you can possibly find.

content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												Republic Commando is a FANTASTIC game, one of the greatest Star Wars games ever made and unquestionably the best Star Wars first-person shooter ever made (I do not count Jedi Outcast or Jedi Academy, because the lightsabers kind of radically change those games to the point where they no longer really qualify). The squad AI is still incredibly good by today's standards, the characters are compelling and smartly-written, and the environments and story are original and creative.But I cannot openly recommend getting this on Steam without some qualifying statements.Republic Commando is an old game. A very old game. And it does not play nicely with newer computers. Problems with bumpmapping in the graphics can result in crashes, and trying to get it to run on a 64-bit Windows OS is a horrific struggle. If you have Windows 7 or 8 64-bit, Republic Commando may need to be sadly relegated to the history books. Hopefully your memories, if you got a chance to play it back in the day. You will likely not get another.EDIT: Ever since I upgraded to Windows 10, it's worked perfectly. I don't know what changed, but I hereby retract the preceding paragraph. In the interests of transparency, I will leave it up, but the compatibility issues probably won't affect you anymore.

content:
Posted: August 7, 2016
												This may seem like an exaggeration, but Star Wars: Republic Commando may be the best game I've ever played. I am a huge Star Wars fan, and I actually found out about this game from the  tie-in novels [www.amazon.com]. I bought this game during a sale and mostly left it alone until recently. Now, after playing it for a few hours, I can confirm that it is everything that its small but fanatic cult following says it is.This depiction of the Star Wars universe is much darker than any other I've encountered before. Rather than following the heroic Jedi in an unrealistic "good vs evil" fight, Republic Commandos occupy that "gray area" and win their fights through brutal efficiency. In fact, Jedi don't even play a significant role in this game. Also, rather than showing typical sanitized Star Wars death (no blood), gratuitous amounts of gore frequently splatters the player's helmet (yay), which is eventually cleaned by a nifty windshield wiper-like device.Gameplay is heavily centered around a squad of four, where the leader is controlled by the player. Commands are given to the other three soldiers, consisting of a sniper, a demolitions expert, and a hacker. AI teammates are actually useful in this game without making it too easy for the player (take notes, Overkill). Each member can be told to perform certain tasks, such as manning a turret, blowing a door open, or providing sniper fire. Everything feels seamless and well-executed, especially the  door breach maneuver . #SquadGoalsGraphics are, well, 2005. Can't expect much. The resolution doesn't even go to 1080p. Thankfully, there are mods to fix that. They're good enough to create a reasonably immersive environment, but I'd like to think that it's the story and gameplay that makes this game what it is. The soundtrack fills in the rest of the atmosphere, which is a combination of John Williams glory and some original compositions. Good music is pretty much a given for anything Star Wars related.About the story (SPOILERS AHEAD): I haven't played through the entire game yet, but I've played enough and have read enough of the novels to get a sense of what's going on.Late in the game, one of the commandos, RC-1207 or "Sev", is left behind on the planet of Kashyyyk following a botched extraction. The game then ends on a cliffhanger regarding the fate of Sev. The game then ends on that cliffhanger. In the novel, Sev's former drill sergeant and father figure Kal Skirata then embarks on a long journey to find him. Unfortunately, thanks to LucasArts getting really messed up and its transition to Disney, both the sequel to this game and the sequel to  Imperial Commando [www.amazon.com] were cancelled. There have been rumors that  EA will release a sequel [www.technobuffalo.com] and that  Sev is alive [www.polygon.com]. However, they are only rumors that we can only hope are true. TL;DR: Underrated squad-based first person shooter with great mechanics and story. Give sequel pls

number of helpful: 19 of 20 people (95%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 17
-Quick Review-Star Wars Republic Commando is a squad based FPS set in the Star Wars universe right at the start of the Battle of Geonosis and ending right at the battle for Kashyyyk. Republic Commando was developed by LucasArts and released March 1, 2005.


At last! Droid and Wookie can stand and have an equal conversation. 
A Screenshot of STAR WARS™ Republic Commando
By: Atratzu




-Detailed breakdown review-Story: You join up with the Delta Squad, an elite group of clones whom have been cloned from the Mandalorian Bounty Hunter Jango Fett. They were also hand picked by Jango Fett to become commando's. The Delta Squad batch of clones were all raised in the same pod group, they're actually one of the closest knit clone groups.Okay PAUSE the review... I personally already had a vested interest in this game because I've read several of the Author Karen Traviss' Republic Commando Books. While Disney (and George Lucas) no longer accepts these books as cannon... ...Don't get me started, I'm just going to accept it and move on.I still prefer the ties between the series. That said, there's a lot of additional character development given to the Delta Squad from her books. Honestly the Nulls are way better, ORDO ALL THE WAY BABY! ..but I digress.


RC-1140 (Fixer... In the Green), RC-1207 (Sev... in the Red), and RC-1262 (Scorch... in the Yellow). 
A Screenshot of STAR WARS™ Republic Commando
By: Atratzu




The four Delta Characters are RC-1140 (Fixer), RC-1207 (Sev), and RC-1262 (Scorch) and you play as RC-1138 (Boss). Here's another reason to respect the game developers, the voice actor for Boss is the actual actor for Jango Fett himself: Temuera Morrison.(However each clone should have his voice, but the game developers gave all of the clones voiced different voice actors... Lets just pretend this is how they hear each other differently, because in Karen Traviss' Books they knew the difference between eachothers voices, but it was only clones and people who got to know them on a personal level would notice the subtle differences. ....aaaaaand it would be very difficult for a gamer to notice difference between the clones voices, let alone instructing a voice actor to change their voice just enough to be different.... BAH. It's complicated, just know I thought about it and attempted to explain it.)Anyway, to recap with less words: Republic Commando story on it's own is kind of shallow because there's very little character development. HOWEVER if you go read the Republic Commando Book series from Karen Traviss then you'll have a whole new level of appreciation for each of these clones.Multiplayer:Just a quick note about the multiplayer, it's gone. Since Gamespy was shut down the servers aren't there. There might still be communities and mod's which you can use to play it with other people though.Gameplay: Before I jump right in and explain the gameplay, lets fix something real quick. When you boot the game the resolution will probably be all wrong, and your mouse will probably be traveling lightspeed all over the screen if you full screen it (ALT + Enter)This guide helped me fix it.Basically you want to open your console mode with your Tilda key: ~ and then type in:setres 1920x1200setmousesensitivity 0.5Even then my mouse moved super fast, and would just use arrow keys to navigate menu's... but it makes the game much more playable. (Final side note: you need to join a game before you can get into the console commands, you can start a LAN game, or jump into a single player campaign game)You have all of the features of a standard FPS in this game, fire, zoom, crouch. The buttons are a wee bit weird at times, like you zoom with Z, and you throw grenades with your right mouse button throws a grenade. (Yeah, that was an unpleasant discovery. I was looking at a wall when I did that.)You Can jump too... but you really won't use that, you also can't sprint... it's the reverse, if you hit shift you move slower. Both of those were weird design choices, but I'm just going to blame it on being the 2000's when this game came out. We're probably lucky it turned out as well as it did.I think it's pretty safe to say most people have played FPS before, and so you come to expect easy and medium difficulties to be relatively challengeless and the only real challenge come from hard mode onward... This is not the case for Republic Commando, I played on medium difficulty (I didn't notice you could change the difficulty until I was half way through, and there's no way I'm switching difficulty half way through a game. Forget that noise.)Most of the challenge in this game comes from the team-oriented gameplay and game design. I normally exploited the AI's design, and let my team mates be cannon fodder while I set bombs, or knifed battle droids in the back of their armor plates... but even with that advantage the game can be down right brutally difficult. Especially if you run out of ammo! Which happened more frequently then I'd like to admit. (I became very well antiquated with the melee button... which is E by the way)


Campaign Mission Selection Map. It averages about 5 levels per planet/ship. For a total game time of 10 hours, that's pretty decent. 
A Screenshot of STAR WARS™ Republic Commando
By: Atratzu




There's about 5 levels on each world, I took roughly 10 hours to play through the whole game, and in my opinion hearing the song "Vode An" and a few Mando'a words and curses was definitely worth the price of admission for me.Conclusion: I really enjoyed my time spent with Republic Commando, unfortunately I'm disappointed there wasn't really any character development, the controls were awkward at times, and the technical problems you're bound to have with older titles.I was very pleased with the Mando'a tribe, the cutscenes, and the effort given to small details which Fandalorians will definitely pick up on and after hearing Vode An I realized I have a new ringtone for my phone.I hate to say it, but I don't think Republic Commando will appeal to everyone equally. But that being said anyone who enjoyed the clone wars era of star wars, and especially anyone who has read Karen Traviss' books should totally check this game out.Oya Manda!

content:
Posted: October 16, 2014
												Tinkering might be needed.I needed to set "bump" setting in the video option to low. Then I could set everything else to highest.  Otherwise it would crash (Found this inf. on the internets).So now that I am 90 minutes into it I can see why everyone loved this game. Its a solid FPS. The guns are not great but the action is exciting, the voice acting is sooo much better than today's crappy FPS games. The music is awesome.  Your NPC buddies are kick **s. The world is simple old lo res but full of atmosphere.  It's smooth.  I'm enjoying it... It's supposed to be about 10 hours which is fine with me. It's too dated for me to put more then 10 hours into it. But it's more then worth a $1 per hour.  For instance, I managed to enjoy shadow of mordor (at least the killing chieftans) because of cutting edge animations and fun high res combat ** DESPITE the horrible  generic characters, awful forgettable plot lines, dreary music,  and repetitive environments. This game you will get as muchvalue for your money. The combat animations suck and the shooting is not the greatest(but it's OK - and there is some tactical parts) but the GAME as a whole is well conceived and extremely well executed. It's better than the AAA titles of the modern era. **I know Mordor is not a FPS so the comparison is not 1:1 but it's the last game I played and the most "new" and slickest game to have been released so I'm just comparing value and I'm making a case for trying out this dated title. 												Finally, some external marketing of Star Wars that does the franchise perfect justice.This game may be older, but it's one of the greatest and still relevant shooters I've played today.Tired of the jedis? Or massive Battlefront-style unit management? Take control of Delta Squad: an elite group of clones who all have their own specialties to bring to the team, and personalities that play well off one another in the amsuing dialouge.The shooting feels pretty good. Enemies die in a lot of visually pleasing and hilarious ways, keeping the good cartoon/serious balance Star Wars is known for. While there's a dissapointing variety of guns, the ones you have suit you very well.As Delta Squad's leader, you take advantage of "squad commands". Split up your three squad members to take up sniper positions, heal themselves, hack consoles, breach doors, blow things up, and a variety of helpful things. All these commands are administered and canceled with suprising ease, and the AI is FANTASTIC at fending for themselves and executing orders.Almost shameful to say that your team AI is better than most cooperative shooter-style games on the market today.You only play through three worlds. While the game isn't longer than eight or so hours, it's one long thrill-ride that is action packed with appropriate breathing room. Nothing's more intense than when you're the last of your squad not incapacitated and there's a pod dispensing Super Battle Droids infront of you.There's multiplayer. It's standard deathmatch and CTF type gamemodes. It's nothing special and nobody really plays it anymore.TL;DR?FANTASTIC shooter, very unique, BLEEDS Star Wars atmosphere, entertaining and likable characterss, and holds up as one of the greatest shooters and Star Wars games today. What's not to like?

content:
Posted: January 30, 2015
												Even as an old game, it's simply brilliant and brilliantly simple.Even on the easiest difficulty, it's extremely difficult.Republic Commando takes place during my favorite point in Star Wars history, the Clone Wars, and provides an interesting story that provides a few layers of depth to the Grand Army of the Republic. Unlike most shooters, such as Battlefield and Child Online Daycare, your weapon isn't the strongest thing you have (in fact, it's kind of weak sometimes) - it's your squad. When presented with seemingly-unstoppable enemies such as droidekas and super battle droids, you'll need every single rifle aimed at the target. You cannot just blitz through the levels, like you can in most games. It requires a lot of skill and coordination, that both add up to make Republic Commando a very challenging game,  but also a really fun one.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												In my opinion Star Wars Republic Commando has to be one of the best first-person shooters made to date. This is because:1. The combat feels great! running at a group of droids firing away at you with just the right amount of accuracy to be a threat and then dispatching them one by one with your wristblade is one of the best experiences in gaming!2. The Team. Your team is made up of 4 people (no spoilers, as you find this all out in the opening) you, the elite Delta 38, the sniper Sev (Delta 07), the hot headed demolitions expert scorch (Delta 62), and the trustworthy commando fixer (Delta 40). Your command over them is relatively limited as you only have 4 options, Search and destroy, Form up, Stay here and Do thing (sniper point, grenade point, breach door, hack, etc) Also if you "die" your squad will carry on fighting until finished and then will revive you with half health (you can order them to revive you sooner but that often puts them in a very vulnerable spot).3.The environments, without spoiling the game for you the envoronments range from full on battles with other troopers present to creepy environments with your enemies lurking around every other corner.4. The story. The story really attaches you mentally to your squad and by the end you'll be scolding scorch for shooting you in the back rather than cursing the AI, and there are some real moments of accomplishment in the story such as the end of the first "chapter". The ending is awesome too!.So to sum up, GO BUY THIS GAME!

number of helpful: 14 of 15 people (93%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 25
												Republic Commando is a very good game, though due to the multiplayer servers being shut down your pretty much paying for a 8-10 hour campagin. (Hamachi, Gameranger, and Orgin can be used to play multiplayer but I am unaware of how much people play)This is currently the only Tactical Star Wars shooter to date so compared to other Star Wars shooters out there it is very good and refreshing for me.Pros: Very good AI teammates.Good ways to make use of the enviroment tactically. The health system is nice, not too easy like regeneration nor not too hard like health pickups.Great Variety of enemies, Super Battle Droids fight like a super battle droid would. They get a bonus for making standard battle droids look somewhat more menecing.Intresting Story.Gun Fights feel like real tactical gun fights.Realistic Door Breaching and squad teamwork.Cons:The design of the Commandos is odd for me, they look too "super human" if you will.The campagin is only 8-10 hours and it is really the only thing your getting.Trandoshon weapons resemble real world gunpowder firearms way too much for my liking.Despite being short the way the levels of the campagin are designed makes you feel like your grinding in some areas.For those wondering...IS THIS GAME'S STORY CANON? (SPOILERS)For the most part no, anything that was not the Movies or the Clone Wars animated series were never really canon and they everything that was not the movies or the clone wars series were offically decanonized by Lucasfilm after the company got sold. IS THE CHARACTERS, WEAPONS, AND OTHER ELEMENTS CANON?Some things yes, Delta Squad made an apperance in the Clone Wars animated series thus making them canon. The Trandoshon Shotgun also made an appearance in the Clone Wars along with it being in a EA's Star Wars Battlefront DLC named the "scatter gun" (loved using it in both games)Other things no, The follow up to Battle of Kashyyyk does not line up with how it happend in Revenge of the Sith (this was made prior to the movie so that is understandable)General Grevious resembles the 2003 cartoon so i'd assume if he had any lines in this he would sound like he did in that series thus making his role in this game non canon by default.In canon the Trandoshons do in fact use regular blasters and when their shotgun made an appearance in the Clone Wars it did not eject any shells.

												I can't get over how stunningly well this game holds up to the test of time.  I used to game away at Republic Commando when I was but a wee lad, though I never finished it because of that timed level at the end of the first act (let me just get it out of the way, that's probably the biggest doozy in this game).  I've since come back and completed it, but as a child, whoo, was that level rough.  If you can get past an occasional sharp difficulty curve through impressive strategy or dogged pursuit of your goals, you'll find this to be one of the most rewarding experiences you've ever had in a shooter.  It's polished, impressive, tense at parts, and will thrill you despite the limited mechanics.In summary, singlehandedly one of the greatest shooters I've ever played.

number of helpful: 11 of 11 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 29, 2016
												Alright, this game is AWESOME.  Star Wars Republic Commando is an FPS based on the lives of Delta Squad, 4 elite clone commandos who are sent on the most dangerous and imperative missions the republic has to offer.  Each one has his own distinct personality and all 4 of them (you play as squad leader) are pretty likable characters.  Here are the commandos in order:38 "three-eight" aka "Boss" or "Sir"- the squad leader and the player character. He is fully voiced by Temuera Morrison, the voice actor for Boba and Jango Fett in the films.  38 (said literally "three-eight")  is a no nonsense commander with a head for strategy and a dry sense of humor.  He leads the squad (obviously) and is able to issue orders to the other 3 commandos, for example, he can tell them to set up sniper positions, anti armor, mount turrets, use healing stations, etc.  (btw these are actual game mechanics, issueing orders to your squad is a huge part of the game).  He has all the weapons that the other 3 commandos are capable of wielding but unlike the others he is capable of using special, enemy weapons that can be found off certain foes.  40 "four-oh" aka "Fixer"- Fixer is the tech specialist of the squad and specialises in hacking and computer interfaces, he is very useful for hacking terminals.  While all the commandos have the same skills and abilities, some are better than others at certain things.  For example, Fixer can hack faster than the others, Scorch is more accurate with grenades and can set explosives faster and Sev is a deadeye with a sniper rifle.  Fixer takes his job verrry seriously and doesn't talk about much other than the mission or how to accomplish it, but he does have moments where he loosens up.  Fixer is exceptional at melee combat and dispatches melee using foes with ease.  62 "six-two" aka "Scorch"-  Scorch is the squad demolitionist and explosive expert and his outlook on life relfects that.  He loves danger and has a very positive, optimistic viewpoint on any sitution, using humor to deal with even the most harrowing of missions.  He is the squad funny guy and his upbeat personality is definitely helpful when things look grim.  Scorch's preferred weapon of choice is the anti-armor grenade launcher and grenades themselves.     07 "oh-seven" aka "Sev"-  Sev is the designated marksman and stealth fighter of the squad and revels in war and battle.  He is a deadly sniper and the best shot in the squad (other than the player).  He is probably the most mandalorian out of the squad and by that I mean he lives for war.  62 finds his fervor for killing to be a bit creepy at times but he is a good soldier and a good friend... and a truly terrible enemy.  Sev's weapon of choice is the sniper rifle, which he uses with pinpoint accuracy.   The game's combat is pretty good and the squad AI is amazing even for today, the commandos feel very human and real.  The game even has multiplayer which I'm not sure if there is anyone on it anymore but it was good in its own way as well.  The story is pretty good and involving and gets pretty hectic at times which keeps things interesting.  All in all this is one of the best star wars games out there and I highly reccomend it for any star wars fan.  I know I spent most of this review talking about the characters, but I did so because they are  the game's strongest attribute.

content:
Posted: April 7
												It's really good, gameplay is good, A.I can be stupid sometimes but telling them to form up or to hold a position can fix their positioning. It's a good game.Pros- -Squad combat is good (their accuracy and damage can be bad at times however) -Multiple weapon types that feel different- Good story - Your squad actually has character - Difficult at the right times (although there are a few unfair moments)- Game took 8 hours to complete (which is good for a good price) and I mostly had fun through the entire gameCons--The default rifle can't do damage for s**t- Some enemies are annoying to fight without the right weapons, killing a super battle droid or the spider tanks without special weapons or grenades is unnessicarily long (yeah yeah difficulty and challenge whatever) - Some sections were a little longer than i would've liked (like the wookie missions) - Bugs- Weird hit detection at times (not that big of a problem just thought i'd mention it, dont try shooting over boxes) - Unfair difficulty spikes - Don't hack or place charges, get a squadmate to do it because your squad will NOT be able to cover you - You can hack or breach doors, but theres really only a few times where hacking it will be helpful. Hacking takes longer and with breaching your squad takes cover and even throws a grenade after breaching, so theres no reason to hack (TL;DR, theres 2 ways to open doors and only one of them is helpful)  Cliffhanger ending  like honestly wtf happened to my edge lord Sev There was more cons than pros but the cons were either minor annoyances or things I felt the game could've gone without. It's a good game and I would reccomend it when it goes on sale. R.I.P good star wars games 7/10

content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
												I know I'm a bit late to the party on this one since the game was released almost 11 years ago as of this review, but this game is actually pretty good for what is. The game is fairly challenging, the AI honestly isn't half-bad, and the overall gameplay is pretty damn good; the music is great, the voice acting is solid, and the game actually looks pretty good for its time. My only real gripes are that the game feels a bit short for the campaign (personal opinion, I just felt that it was a bit shorter than what I expected) and that the ending feels like a bit of a cop-out since it leaves the player feeling as if there's going to be a sequel (which we all know is unfortunately never happening). I'd definitely say something about the multiplayer as well if I could, but since the multiplayer has been rendered non-functional due to GameSpy's shutdown, I'm unfortunately not able to do so.In the end, I'd definitely say that this is a game I'd recommend, even without the multiplayer being functional.

number of helpful: 9 of 9 people (100%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 14, 2016
												Star Wars Republic Commando is such a unique and addicting game that I find it may even rival the Battlefront series.Basically you are the squad leader of a 4 person squad.Delta 40Delta 62 Delta 07And you, Delta 38. Together, you form the Delta Squad. You are clone troopers that have been engineered to be the best of the best. You are the future. You are the commandos. You must strategically command your squad in order to beat back the droid army on various missions across various planets. Something i'd like to mention is that the droids are very tough in this game, while in the movie they seemed like bumbling pieces of metal that could easily be taken down.  Initially I started the game on normal but had to change it to easy because it was too hard. I may re-play the game on medium though. But even on easy, the separatists are a force to be reckoned with and the enemies are remarkably tough. This makes for thrilling gameplay as all the responsibility falls on your shoulders as the squad leader, and you must make hard decisions. In the end, only 2 things matter. Win the battle, and get your squad out alive. But later in the game, you must choose which is more important....Each squad member has a unique personality, and as the game progresses you feel very close to them. The members are: Scorch, (62)Fixer, (40) Sev, (07) And you, 38. Or, Boss.You are alone, cut off, and all you have is your squad. You do whatever it takes to save them. I'll never get tired of hearing:Engage snipe maneuver, Delta.Rearrange some architecture, commando.I want some explosives here, Delta!Stop limping around and get some bacta, soldier.Engage anti armor position, delta!Something i'd like to mention is that your character's full number is actually 1138. 38 is just for short. I think that's cool because THX-1138 was a screenplay George Lucas wrote in college. So that's a neat little Easter egg there.And also, at the end of the game you can hear the x wing pilots from a New Hope saying things they said during the Death  Star run. So that's another cool little Easter egg. I also like how you can attack your squad, and they fight back! I tried killing my squad mates one time, and found myself fighting against them. I actually felt really bad. XDThis game is spectacular, extremely fun, unique, and a must-buy. It was so much fun for me because I am a HUGE fan of the Clone Troopers. I just think they're really cool, and being able to not only be one, but be a commander throughout this game, was an incredible experience.I would definitely, whole heartily recommend this game. The only thing I'm disappointed about is that there isn't more. I thought there'd be several more planets and missions leading up to Order 66. Oh well, maybe there will be a sequel in the future called Imperial Commando. (Just please don't have EA make it) I give this game a 10/10.The game is extremely fun with a great story, good voice actors, great controls, hard bosses that require strategy to take down, good weapons, great graphics, and a great atmosphere. Would play again.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2013
												Star Wars Republic Commando is a unique experience for a Star Wars game. You don't play as a Jedi or a Bounty Hunter or any of the things in between. Instead you get plopped directly into the head of a Clone trooper and thrown onto the battlefields of Episode Two.As a clone trooper you don't get much back story or indeed any motivation beyond the occasional communication pop-up on your UI that tells you where to go next. Indeed you were bred for combat and unquestioning loyalty and that's what you do. This rather unique aspect does a lot of alleviate many of the problems that usually plague Star Wars games and makes Republic Commando a rather enjoyable experience.You are not just any Clone Trooper however, you are a squad leader and this is where the gameplay of Republic Commando comes into play. With you have 3 additional commandos, each with their own area of expertise. A sniper, a demolitions expert and a hacker. As you go through the missions you will be able to order your team around, into cover, mounting gun positions, or performing specific tasks suited to their specialty through a context sensitive command system. You basically just point at an object and click and one of your squad members takes the appropriate action. This all works surprisingly well and trying to play the game as a lone wolf tends to end badly as the game features some rather impressive AI, both on the part of your teammates and the enemies.The game is very pretty and in particular the background deserves notice as there is always something else going on there which often looks every bit as intense as the fight you are distracted from.The voice-acting is pretty good for a game but you will quickly realize that the developers took a little shortcut here as the many different voices and accents the clones have makes you wonder just how similar they really are.Star Wars Republic Commando is an attempt to take the Star Wars franchise into the squad based tactical genre and it comes away from the attempt quite nicely although it is a game that has it's flaws, most notably the campaign is extremely short and ends with a cliffhanger that's never resolved as this is the only game in the franchise. Still all in all it's one of the best Star Wars games out there and one of those that can be held up as a good game in it's own right.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
												As a Star Wars fan, this was fun.  It's a first person shooter, has nothing to do with the elite characters of the movie, instead you are a clone trooper.  The teamwork works great, at least they listen to what you want them to do.  Outside of that, the AI isn't great for either your partners or for the enemies.  There are a variety of enemies, some that are rather tough, and others that just annoy.  The weapons are decent, but nothing spectacularly new.  The storyline is intriguing and connects somewhat well within the Star Wars Universe.  The fun, didn't last through the entire game though as the game gets quite repetitive.  The graphics aren't too interesting to look at these days, and this isn't to say that they aren't good, just that there's no real art design that stands out.  Everything seems bleak and without much detail.If you are not a Star Wars fan, this may not tickle your fancy.  However, it's a short game that can easily be beaten in less than 10 hours.  I enjoyed it.

												It's not very often a Star Wars game (specifically this one) goes on sale. I remember playing this a few years ago when it first came out, just picked it up on Steam, too. Had loads of fun playing the campaign, lots of great memories from this game. I remember hugging the healing stations because I was worried I'd get killed during the next fight all the time.You can play as different specialized Clone Troopers (i.e. Demolitions, Sniper, etc.).This is actually one of those games where commanding your own squad is fun. The AI is decent (not perfect, but close enough). You can use turrets from fallen Republic Gunships and mow down enemies with it. All in all, a great game.. multiplayer wasn't that bad too. I had lots of fun dueling 1v1. One day, I was lucky enough to pull a direct headshot by bouncing a Wookie crossbow projectile off the wall on somebody. :D: Been a while, and I can't remember the name of the map, but it was an arena map called "Clone Training".I give the game a 8.5/10. Although the game was pretty enjoyable, I remember it being short (a few hours only) and there were some brutal levels.. well, that's AI squad-based gameplay for ya. Anyways, you can listen to me yap all day, but this goes on my list of Top 10 SW video games ever released. It's on sale right now for just $3, worth buying if you're a fan of Star Wars.

number of helpful: 8 of 8 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 24, 2016
												"GET YOURSELF SOME BACTA, SOLDIER"The prequels were flawed yes, but at least the Episodes II-III era (2002-2005) spawned some sweet SW games, for many the last great era for LucasArts (everything went downhill after 2005).Republic Commando is "THE" SW shooter, by that I mean the best SW shooter of all time (unless Dark Forces gets a remake, which is unlikely next to impossible). The Halo 2-Half 2 influence is evident (minus riding a vehicle and the gravity gun) and the game tries to be lean and mean (not bloody though). Explosions and melee attacks are everywhere, and the cheesy-cute humor of the prequels is nowhere to be found. Overall the game provides a solid Clone Wars experience.The graphics still look very good for a mid-00s game and the sound design is superb.But sadly, the game has some clear flaws, which put the game in a  8-8.5 out of 10 zone at best (it could have been a 10 out of 10)a) too short (like 4-5 hours on easy). Also, some people will find frustrating that there are only three (extended) maps: Geonosis, Republic Ship and Kashyyyk. b) the AI of the squad is not that great, they get killed easily on medium difficulty.c) some enemies are ridiculously overpowered and hard to kill without heavy weapons (which are hard to find)That said, the game was loved-popular enough so fans demanded a sequel, which never came due to the mismanagement of LucasArts that slowly killed the company until its 2012 disappearance.

content:
Posted: April 11
												This is literally a better Halo 5 from the story, to the AI and actual presence of squad commands, to the balance, and even the gameplay.Some people say the game is short and that's primarily because it's split up into 3 distinct campaigns which maybe about 2 hours a piece. Not bad especially considering the price. But where this game shines so well is the squad command. It may only consist of 4 basic commands, target a specific enemy, and attach to cover (grenade, anti-armor, or sniper position) but the way it implements it is so beautiful.You, as the leader of Delta Squad, have to constantly balance between defense and offense in a wide variety of scenarios and above all else it makes it feel like the combat is alive more than anything else. At any moment you have to react to something and figure out how to tell your squad to deal with it. And the great thing is: They are NOT dumb AI, they may be among the best AI I've seen so far and this game was made in 2005. Which if you fail you can't blame it on the AI, they did they're job meaning you failed yours. The responsibility to win any engagement falls squarely on you because your squad will perform and often perform very well. And somehow that makes it a game of personal skill in a squad command game and it's bloody fantastic. I love this game to pieces for that.And beyond that like I said earlier the story is great, it really does makes you feel like you're an elite Clone squad during the Clone Wars. The immersion is absolutley perfect and the squad mates accompying you all have distinct personalities are quite interesting. They even often say things during combat that range from helpful to entertaining.If anything this game left me wanting for so much more because what I got was amazing. Which is why I'm giving it my first non-humor 10/10. I will ALWAYS love this game, it is easily worth more than the price you're charged for it.

number of helpful: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 16, 2016
A game ahead of its time Star Wars Rebublic Commando is set in the early stages of the Clone Wars. You are a clone commander in charge of Delta Squad, the republics deadliest soldiers. You and your squad are sent behind enemy lines and must fight the droids of CIS (confederacy of independent systems) However, the droids are not the only threat you must face.A very clever and simple squad based gameplayWhen I first dove into the game, I was expecting a squad based system which would be confusing, similar to Red Orchestra 2. The system was actually pretty simple. It did not take long to learn the mechanics. You have just a few buttons which you can use to give your squad commands. Commands such as defend this area, follow me, advance (search and destroy), cancel orders. You can also order your men to different highlighted positions like, sniper,anti armor, turrets and grenade. Might sound confusing, but it really isn't. I was surprised of the good physics in this game and the gameplay itself was fun, but only for a couple of hours. The maps and basic gameplay got a bit repetitive and I got bored after a half an hour or so each session. Still, it was fun and entertaining.Short and loose storythe story was not as good as I hoped. You get a short prolouge cutscene that tells you about the clone commandos. The story jumps from one place to the next. At first you are at Geonosis and suddenly you are investigating a lost republic war ship. So it is not a direct storyline throughout the game. What I did like was the chatter between your men. It was funny at many occasions and you got more feelings about your men. It also ends with a cliffhanger and since republic commando 2 was cancelled I doubt that there will be a sequel anytime soon. Though, the developers leaked information about how the story would continue, so the ending is still there.Worth it?It was a game ahead of its time, so I can't complain about anything really, except the story. Other than the story being very loose I would still recommend bying it, especially if you are a Star Wars fan. The music is top notch. Note: Multiplayer does not work anymore, so you will only be able to play singleplayer, still worth it though

content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
												A Star Wars game without any Jedi around, instead focusing on squad-based battles and tactical combat solving. As an FPS it takes inspiration from all the right sources, including Metroid Prime for its famous HUD.Pros* Tacticool as ♥♥♥♥. Door breaching, landmine ambush, air support, everything is there* Good ability at creating a believable atmosphere with a mix of large battles and claustrophobic resistance* Excellent OST, with some very bad asses Mandalorian songsCons* Low variety of weapons and enemies* You're never given quite enough ammunition to kill armored droidsNote that the ending is a slightly-frustrating cliffhanger that will likely never be resolved. Make sure to properly order your squaddies around for you won't go far without being a good field officer.

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 8, 2015
												Equal parts tactical strategy game and first-person shooter, Republic Commando proves itself greater than the sum of its parts.  Enemy encounters are varied and fun, in a way that only sci-fi shooters can be with their assortment of alien and robotic adversaries.  Squad commands are doled out in a system that is about as intuitive as possible, at least until voice recognition works its way into the realm of gaming.  On top of it all, great writing that de-emphasizes the Jedi Order does something that George Lucas failed to do; it makes the prequels cool.  Republic Commando is the rare Star Wars game that is more than just a money grab, and you know it because it would be just as good without all of the licensing.  For a full review, check out:http://amanandhismouse.com/republic-commando.html

content:
Posted: January 22
												I love this game. Like this game has single-handedly made me look back into Star Wars games in general. Republic Commando is basically what happens when you make a Tom Clancy game, put it in the Star Wars universe, and make your AI allies actually listen to you. I know, I could hardly understand it myself at first.Your squad actually listens to you instead of going into random rooms (a la Mass Effect) or not doing anything (some Tom Clancy games). But even without the great ally AI, the game still holds up well. The gameplay is surprisingly furious for a mid 2000s shooter, and you'll nearly die many times in the crazy firefights that ensue during the game. The game's multiplayer is also fun (somewhat similar to Halo 1/2's splitscreen multiplayer) but not as lasting as the campaign. The game's story length (~8.5 hours) is also respectable given the depth and action. Did I mention that your allies actually friggin do what you tell them to do, even in a firefight?Honestly the only downside to this game is its lack of sequel. The game ends on an obvious cliffhanger that was meant to segue into a sequel, as one was in development before this even released. Unfortunately the project got cancelled, so the ending just gets left with nothing to follow up on, which is a shame. I wish this game was given as much love as The Force  Unleashed; it'd be more deserving to be sure.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												I liked this game, and keep wondering why there isn't a sequel out given *spoilers* *spoilers* *more spoilers*. I'm hardly a fan of the Star Wars prequels, but the characters and plot are interesting and solid. I especially love the first half of chapter 2, with its "haunted house" feel. I can even get over the fact that Scorch is voiced by Raphael Sbarge (that guy who will forever be Carth Onasi to me and who only has one acting style), given that all the squad's personalities are both clearly defined and show development across the plot-arc. For instance, I love how Fixer is incredibly straitlaced but sometimes the facade cracks, just a little.I also don't play a whole lot of shooters, but I really enjoyed the feeling of being in charge of a squad that reacts to me without a whole lot of complicated keyboard commands to memorize. In fact, there's only one button to direct every terrain-contextualized action, and that's okay with me! A little odd that the boys will get infinite ammo of whatever type they're using while they're in a terrain position, but hey, Scorch lobbing unlimited grenades is also okay with me. The graphics are also fine for how old it is, and I like the little details like the visor windshield wiper for rain/blood/oil/scratches(!?). It was a little frustrating at times when running low on ammo or health and with no way to get more before having to survive difficult waves of enemies, but that's almost certainly because I'm not very good at shooters. :POverall, I really got the feeling that I was part of a team while playing this game, and it was really awesome.
