number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Here's my bottom line opinion on Republic Commando; it's the second-best Star Wars first-person shooter. Just below Dark Forces. It has the unfortunate distinction of being the best game to come out of the prequel trilogy, and doesn't escape the taint of the prequel's legacy. I may even like the ideas behind Republic Commando more than I like the game itself.Here is what sucks about Republic Commando: the weapons sound weak, and there aren't many different enemies to fight. So what does Republic Commando do right? The intro to the game is great. It details where you and your squad came from, all from the first person perspective. In fact, this game takes a page from Half-Life in that the entire game is played from the first-person perspective. There are a couple of scenes where you are not in control of your character, but they're limited.The squad AI is not smart but it's competent. They'll kill enemies, heal themselves, heal you when you drop, take cover, etc. There are certain set pieces that you can order a squadmate to take position at for a specific purpose (like sniping or anti-armor) and they're meant to be used. Your squad dies less when they're in one of these ordered positions. The squad also has fantastic vocal banter. Each member is a personality, and I got attached to them as the game went along.Though the levels are a little cookie cutter, there are plenty of objectives to them and no lack for fights. I was fighting in corridors, in small courtyards and hangers, on multi-level starship bridges, and in trees. They're not as varied as Dark Forces, but each environment is well made.And now I can get to what stops this from being a great game. They can fix the sound effects and toss in a couple more enemies, but it's harder to change the setting. Republic Commando takes place at the onset of the Clone Wars. It starts on Geonosha even. And though it takes place over a two (three?) year span, it could have gone farther. This was a pre-Episode 3 game and it shows. It feels like a teaser leading up to Episode 3 and, ultimately, suffers for that. It doesn't deserve to be timely movie release fodder. It deserves to be treated like a game that can stand on its own two legs. Something that can be taken out of the context of the prequel release. It doesn't deserve to be lumped in with Episode 1 Racer, Star Wars Starfighter, Bounty Hunter, Obi-Wan, or any other godawful prequel game.It doesn't carry the same tone as those games. The developers did their damnedest to give this game a fair chance. They go out of their way to make  you know that you are playing an elite soldier. You're no jedi, and you're not fodder either. You see your share of ally deaths and the Clone War takes its toll. But you're fighting bugs on Geonosha. And battle droids, even if they're way more menacing than they ever were in the prequel movies. They may bleed oil, wear a metallic gray paint job (rather than the orange seen in the movies), and the super battle droids may be some tough ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s, but they're still battle droids, which are inherently lame. There's a pitiful tie in with General Grieveous in the form of his bodyguards, which flip and hop around like acrobats, with electric sticks. They're not threatening in the slightest, more annoying than anything, and serve only to give General Grieveous an excuse to make an unwarranted appearance.What I'm getting down to is that in Republic Commando you are playing, in essence, a proto super stormtrooper. I wish the devs would've been allowed to run with that rather than get tied to the time frame that stuck them between the two prequel movies. I hope we can get another Republic Commando game, but I'm not expecting it. This franchise has legs that get cut out from beneath it by the movies it was made to support.

Posted: February 18, 2015
												If you've played it before and have $10 to spare or if it's on sale, absolutely get it. The community for it mostly gone but if you REALLY want to get some multiplayer action going, there are small groups like ReiGn that will play and have servers up. I may or may not get one myself. There are plenty of mods for the game as well. I haven't put that much time looking into it but I believe there is one that adds an entire new campaign. Never played it before? This game is within that top tier of all Star Wars games ever made. Amazing and unique gameplay + story. The chat between your squad as you progress makes it even better. It can be incredibly challenging even now if you turn the diff. all the way up. The squad mechanic also ups the difficiutly a bit as you will need to utilize them correctly if you want to get anywhere.  You are not a God (i.e a Jedi) in this game and it will remind you if you try to lone wolf it.Like I said the game still looks AMAZING considering how old it is. One thing that makes this stand out in my eyes is that like the story for BF2, this is one is told from the Clone perspetive rather than the overdone Jedi one. All in all yes get this game. Maybe with all the hype coming back to Star Wars with the new movie and BF3 we'll finally get a sequel.

												This has to be one of my favorite games of all time. Not because it is Star Wars or anything like that. Partly cause it is Star Wars actually. But for some reason that never made me as nervous as when I was roaming the abandoned Republic ship as Clones got torn limb from limb in the room next to me. Yes, I could be trying to take down a hunters. But a lot of villains in this game provide much more of a challenge.Another aspect of the game is the squad. You control your squad and tell them where to go. I'm constantly checking my squad's health and changing their positions. Yes, some current games have squads. You kinda control them, but I don't think as much as in this game. But that's just my opinion.With a compelling story and constant threats trying to kill you, this game makes for a great experience.

												This is probably one of the best FPS that are out on the market today. I have been playing this game for 7+ years and have enjoyed every second of it. Before the server shutdown, this was an amazing multiplayer game. There was constantly 50+ people playing per day on every server, and everyone enjoying themselves.As for the campaign, they really put in a lot of detail into this. They were able to establish a squadron of elite troopers known as "Delta Squad" and tell us about their story and what they were able to accomplish. Like any good game with a story, there is also a lot of sad parts, and enjoyable parts. The creators of this game also were able to establish a few easter-eggs for us as the players to figure out, and made the graphics far ahead of its time.All in all, I love this game and always will. If the servers weren't shut down, I would definitley recommend this game for anyone. But if you enjoy Star Wars, and Campaigns, then this is the game for you. One of the best on the market.

content:
Posted: January 10
												Hands down the best Star Wars video game ever made. I've played through it on 3 different systems, multiple times now. If you have any love for the Clone Wars, or even Star Wars as a whole... Or Heck, even if you just love Sci-Fi shooters, you owe it to yourself to try this one.It still looks great today, with anistrophic filtering and texturework nigh on the best of its time. The Steam version goes on sale often and only takes a small mouse acceleration fix for the menus, otherwise it runs like a dream.It is a Squad-Based shooter, done very well. How many of those do you even know of that exist? Besides maybe Rainbow 6. You can and are given incentive to order your men to specific positions, breach maneuvers, or turret mounts, etc... They aren't dumb either, great AI too. They'll prioritize targets as you mark them.Not to mention everyone on the team can do every job, from splicing terminals to planting bombs to setting up sniping nests. You can do all of it too, but if you use the right guy for it, they'll usually do it better.And the story, oh the story... There are 3 zones you'll be going through, going from Geonosis, to something else, to Kashyyyk. I don't want to spoil the 2nd one because, well, it's frankly fantastic atmosphere and all that. Just trust me, Geonosis and Kashyyyk might be average, but the 2nd one, oh man it's great.I... I could keep going, but again just trust me, this game is a Home Run in every way I can think of. Buy it, play it, love it like everyone else who has bought it and played it.

												Zero Dark Thirty - Star Wars Edition. These boys would fit right in with modern day Navy SEALs or US Army Rangers, heck they even have a little SWAT in them. Call of Duty ain't got nothing on this gem. Their personalities are unique and easy going, if you can get used to TMNT then you can handle Delta Squad. The military tactics are down to Earth and easily recongnizable, plus each has a distinct voice unlike the Clone Wars Series were everyone has the same one, gives each one personality only your main character has Jango's voice. So if you are looking for realistic gritty Star Wars without any of those pesky Jedi or Sith, this one is for you. Its nice you can for once block out the Sith or the Jedi and pretend just for a moment Star Wars is actually a WAR and not a philosophical battle between a guy with a red sword and someone else with a (insert color here) sword. Very refreshing. It makes the Star Wars Universe seem not so far away after all and all the more enjoyable.

content:
Posted: May 8, 2016
												This game is worth every cent that I payed and possibly even more if the story was longer! (already a fairly long and fun story, don't worry). I played this game non-stop on the hardest difficulty as soon as I got it and it is honestly perfect in every way. This game, not even kidding in any way, has thebest beginning to any game I've played. The awe that I felt as I saw my character's life begin was simply wonderful and irreplacable, it might just be me but everything about this was just beautiful and unforgettable. Enough of that though (I love this game so f**king much) it's time to go on to your squad. The squad gameplay is amazing and unlike most squad features in most triple A title games nowadays. The basics of what I'm saying are that there's good control over your squad and that without you your squad will likely die and if you're alone you will likey die, only together can you effectively triumph against you enemies both weak and strong. The story itself is fun and effectively gave me a feeling of bonding and love with my team, all of them of distinct personalities and traits that make them unique and lovable, they will even occasionally crack a joke between one another or yell something that makes me laugh or smile. To be completely honest, with how amazing this game is I am very suprised that it isn't as loved or known as star wars battlefront is. I'd much prefer this game over that (despite battlefront being my chidhood and being simply a great game). I really hope that someone eventually comes to finish the series with its canceled sequel otherwise I shall continue to cry at the thought of what could've been.as a final verdict I rate this work of art a 10/10, it has no real failings other than age and at this point I honestly want to play it all over again. (I don't usually give games this good of ratings, only other game to get that high on my list is portal 2). I cannot reccomend this game more if you like squad gameplay and fps games or if you like murderous-deep voiced badasses, funny-somewhat timid, or that one guy who follows orders and is fairly serious about most subjects because that's what this squad consists of and I love tham all.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2014
												One of the best action FPS ever made. It's kinda like a Halo clone but to say it's a ripoff of halo would be unfair. It plays kinda like a first person Ghost Recon or Rainbow Six Vegas but with less strategy. The whole game is just really well made and you can tell the developers put their heart & soul in this. The characters in the game feel so lively and it feels like YOU ARE the commando the entire time. Using the DC-17m with the blaster rifle attachment never gets old and the sounds in the game sound very satisfying from blaster shots to droid noises. It is a rich FPS experience with a cheap price tag. Well worth your money. Easily one of the best star wars game.

content:
Posted: October 23, 2016
												I just finished the game and I just have to say that it's pretty damn good. Especially for its current price.Now, the combat is Bioshock style. Meaning that you just shoot and at some moment the enemy just falls down and is dead. There's no real feedback to the damage you're doing and due to that the gunplay is very unsatisfying. The melee however was strong and it made me take a lot of risks to just take out the enemy. If a game gets me to risk myself and forces me to not play safe without it feeling unfair and just artificial, then I'd say that it does a good job.The story is what it is. It's 3 main campaigns, each is about 2-3 hours. On normal, the game was just as difficult as it should be. I lost the game a few times, but not enough to have the game feel unfair. Almost every death felt like it was my fault and preventable.The graphics look pretty good and the game runs very well as well, even on my 4GB DDR3, FX-4100, GT640.The game's been in many bundles, so it's pretty cheap when it comes to value. You'll be able to trade for it no problem.One problem though was that it ends in an annoying cliffhanger and the last mission also ends very abruptly, which makes me feel that they were just pushing it out as quickly as possible. The A.I. is pretty good for your team, but the same can't be said about your allies and enemies. They usually just sit and do nothing and get themselves killed. I know that all allies are meant to die, but it's just so damn annoying that they die to one minion or something.Overall, is this game worth the full price? If you're not on a shoe-string budget, then yeah. Is it worth a bundle purchase or a trade? Yeah, definitely. Overall 7/10(All games start at a 5/10 and move up/down based on its pros/cons)

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 8, 2014
												This is one of the most criminally-underrated shooters ever made. The game manages to fully immerse the player in the Star Wars universe without using Jedi, force powers, or any other hallmarks typical of the Star Wars franchise. This is a tactical first-person shooter played from the perspective of a Clone Trooper, one of the expendable "mooks" who drop like flies in the movies and are predecessors to the Stormtroopers, the ultimate "disposable bad guy." Each member of the squad is a clone, but they behave with distinctive personalities and voices that make you actually care about them. The game has a fairly good difficulty curve, with the game gradually spacing bacta tanks and ammo dumps farther and farther apart as the game progresses without becoming noticeable. You will need to use teamwork to knock out larger enemies like spider droids, which are almost impossible to down with the limited grenade launcher ammo you have. To drive the importance of team work home, the game has several sections where the squad splits, meaning you have no one to revive you if you die. And you have at most 6 hits on normal difficulty before you're a goner. The presentation is fantastic. The graphics have aged well and it runs smoothly on modern operating systems with no compatibility issues. The soundtrack is a masterpiece, with memorable pieces like the Mandalorian chant "Vode An" punctuating intense action sequences, as well as familiar snippets from the film scores. The game will throw in bits of fan-service such as a squad mate quipping "these must be the droids we're looking for" which just make you chuckle even under pressure. The AI is decent but will occasionally get stuck behind barriers when rushing to revive you, leading to frustration. The cooperative nature of the campaign makes the lack of online co-op campaign play very glaring. If this game ever gets a sequel, this feature needs to be added first. The campaign only features three planets, and is pretty short. None of the multiplayer maps are very interesting. These are probably due to the game's status as a tie-in for Episode III's film release with crunched development time. Just get this game. You will not be disappointed. It's not perfect by any means but its extremely minor flaws do little to hamper an amazing experience. For a 9-year-old game it's extremely playable and not dated at all.

content:
Posted: March 15, 2013
												Republic Commando is a nice squad based first person shooter. Playing as a clone delta squad commander provides a fresh perspective in the Star Wars universe where you get to use a blaster instead of a light saber. The squad based system is simple and easy to use and the AI actually follows orders well. The small assortment of weapons and attachments isn't impressive, but they get the job done. The game offers an engaging tactical story and traditional Star Wars music. There's no in-game options for wide screen resolution support, but you can manually modify some .ini files to get higher resolutions working. And the graphics look decent at 1920x1080.Although there's nothing great about it, Republic Commando is definitely a polished game that is fun from start to finish--worthy of its 2005 release date.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2015
Short version: 87%Star Wars meets Rainbow Six in this tactical FPS, where you lead a group of strangely unique clones against the enemies of the Republic in three different campaigns. It may not be on the levels of Battlefront or the actual Rainbow Six titles, but Republic Commando is still a great game to play.Long version:Star Wars has a really successful and long relationship with the FPS genre, and Republic Commando is no exception. It may be nothing but a Rainbow Six clone in Star Wars costume, but this is hidden behind excellent game design.The story takes place during the Clone Wars, where the player takes the role of a special commando, leading his own squad straight into the heart of enemy lines. (The game is not tied to the animated series.)The settings are a bit clichéd: the battle of Geonosis, a (seemingly) desolate space ship, and Kashyyyk (because there always have to be wookies)… Luckily the writers knew these predictable settings need something to keep interest, so they spoil us with some good dialogues and fast-paced mission structure.The gameplay itself is simplistic squadron-based tactical combat where a single button replaces the command menu. It may be a significant limitation, but the system works as intended. All events are scripted, but you still need to continuously assess the situation and order your squad accordingly.Republic Commando may not reach early Halo levels with the AI, but it has nothing to be ashamed of. Just don’t expect your squad to win the game for you; team management is a very crucial point, especially in hold the line situations.The game didn’t age well from a technical standpoint; modern systems may have a bit of a problem running it properly. But when they do, you are offered one of the best Star Wars games to date to play with.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												This game came out in 2005 and has a much better squad system then halo: reach which came out in 2010. You play as Delta 38 aka Boss, leader of an elite clone commando squad. You lead your squad of 4 commandos across 3 different campaigns during the era of the clone wars. Each campaign is relatively short (around 2 hours) but feel unique enough to give you a different experience through each one. Atmosphere is great and so is the soundtrack. Using your squad effectively is very important to succeed in this game. You can't finish this game by yourself you need to use your AI controled squad. Your squad consists of 3 other commandos that all have different strengths and personalities, which leads to some good interactions and interesting dialogue. The squad commanding is very simple but also one of the most effective ways i've ever seen in any game, even in 2016. the game ends on a cliffhanger ending, originally planned to continue the story in a sequel. unfortunatly this game got scrapped so the game ends with a very important part of the story unexplained. Rating 8.5/10.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												I recommend this for a die hard Star Wars fan. If you're not a fan, then this is a generic shooter that falls down on some areas. Main problem is that the variety of enemies and guns are small, which makes the shooting part pretty boring. The leading of the team is made surprisingly well and the team is most of the time useful. For some reason, the team can only use grenades, sniper rifle and anti-tank weapons on certain specific points, which doesn't offer much of tactical challenge. Most of the time, you order your men to all available positions and run yourself to melee distance where enemy is very lacking. The game hasn't stood the test of time, and lacks memorable moments. Then again the music and sounds are pretty good that makes the atmoshphere quite good. Level design is boring, unmemorable and  and areas between loading times are really short(usually 5-10 minutes). The game doesn't change much after the first few levels. The game lasts for about 5 hours, which is good or bad depending if you like it or not.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												Like a swift kick to the stomach, this game will leave you doubled-over and gasping for breath hours after you finish playing. How many times have I been forced to kill a spider droid on my own with just a pistol because I ran out of ammo and my entire squad is incapacitated, or how often have I encountered a droid dispenser pumping out SBD's only to realize I've already used up all my anti-armor charges? These kinds of situations force to think ahead and plan & execute your strategies quickly. Keeping your squad organized is key. It's a beatiful thing when you give your squadmates commands and then find out that what you've decided for them to do is the perfect strategy. Good ol' Delta 38... he always knows just what to do.Squad control in the game is easy as pie, and the friendly AI is okay, though at times a bit frustrating. When they're given a command, the squad will go do it no matter what, even if it means doing something dumb like getting killed because they don't think to kill the things in their way first. Enemies are pretty stupid, but you don't need to be smart when you're a Super Battle Droid. The graphics and landscapes are dated but still amazing, from the windy, dusty canyons of Geonosis to the dark and foreboding forests of Kashyyyk. Except for the commando armor, everything is dark and gloomy. Gameplay is also awesome; everything is fast-paced and keeps you on the edge of your seat (and sometimes out of it completely). Whether you're desperately trying to hold off an endless stream of enemies as one of your squadmates plants explosives on a droid dispenser while another hacks into a security system while under fire, or you're clearing a path through a group of fat Trandoshan slavers in the maze-like corridors of an assault ship, there's never a dull moment in Republic Commando, and the hard difficulty mode is just right.The Squad:Delta 38, the main character. A tough-as-nails commando, 38 don't take no crap from nobody. Even when under heavy fire, he calmly gives commands like he's ordering food at a McDonald's drive-thru. He's the voice of reason, keeping everybody under control.Delta 62 (Scorch), the Demolitions expert. Scorch likes explosives. That's all there is to say.Delta 07 (Sev), is a fierce hunter. His best use is as a sniper, providing amazingly accurate covering fire for his squadmates. His only job is to kill, kill, kill.Delta 40 (Fixer), is just a good old-fashioned soldier. He's uncomplicated and a great fighter, and always follows orders. Other than that, I'm not quite sure what his deal is... I guess he's the "computer expert," though any commando can slice any console.Each commando has his own personality. Scorch can be quite humorous at times, and Sev has some pretty disturbing things to say. One thing I don't understand is why do all have different voices? I though they were all the same clones...Trust me when I saw that even still to this day this game is worth every penny. The only thing I wish is that more games could be like this.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												Back in 2005, Star Wars: Republic Commando was an unsung gaming classic, since then it has aged incredibly well in the gameplay department, standing defiant against both the tides of time and the trends of cover-based shooting and regenerating health. The gameplay, weapons, squad mechanics and even the graphics are still appealing even after all this time. The Steam release of Republic Commando is the third time I have bought this game, and I still love to play it now and again.The first thing that LucasArts got right with this game is making the Commados feel just as bad♥♥♥♥♥as the Jedi, while at the same time making them feel like soldiers. This is accomplished simply with the squad commands and context-dependant actions such as sniping and grenade positions. The scripted animations are icing on the cake like tackling droidekas or killing a kamikazi trandoshan with his own knives.But while each member of Delta Squad is comprehensively a one-man killing machine, they are not as invincible as a Jedi Knight, you need your squad, and again this really enhances the military feel of the game. Performing door breaches, setting up entrenched positions, and setting up covering fire while you outflank the enemy do a great deal to give Republic Commando a military feel that few modern military shooters can match. Putting you in command of Delta Squad was an awesome idea.Atmosphere is another area where this game shines. You start out being dropped behing enemy lines onto Geonosis, fighting your way into a Geonosian hive complex, down through a droid foundry and into a trade federation droid control ship. Then comes the genuinely creepy ghost-ship mission where you will be reduced to being hunted, alone by scavenger droids, and finally you will form part of the first wave in the republic's campaign on Kashyyyk, each location feels unique, and the game manages to capture the frenetic pace of a battlefield, the isolation and helplessness of a horror game, and the epic scale of a megaflora jungle.While some games start to feel dated and klunky as technology and design practices roll on, Republic Commando was at least 10 years ahead of its time. Everything about it shines, and the few flaws are minor and easily overlooked. Even when it's not on sale, this game is a bargain at ten bucks, the only negative point I can hold against Republic Commando is that it wasn't long enough and never had a sequel.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 15, 2015
												This is an amazing game, and probably my favourite FPS.It's also very short. There are three mini campaigns, which you play through sequentially. One on Geonosis, one onboard a Republic cruiser and one on Kashyyyk, all of them clock in at around 2 hours each.With that big, primary concern out of the way, do I recommend this game? I sure do.Beyond nailing the aesthetic of the Clone Wars (more the one from the films than the tv series) or even Star Wars in general it is a solid single player squad based shooter.Single player and squad based might sound like opposing descriptors, but they're not. The three titular Commandos are your greatest weapon, both in effectiveness and enjoyment. Every Commando can do what you do, at the same rate.Do you want to dash in behind the enemy battle droids and take out their dispenser or do you want to send one of your squad mates to do it so you can lay down covering fire? You'll have them hack their way into power generators to reactivate them, but could just as well do that yourself.Should they fall you can revive them by running up to them with a defibrillator, or order one of the remaining squad mates to do that. Even if you get shot down yourself your squad mates will, at your orders, run over and put you back on your feet.Opposing you are the expected Trade Federation droids, the Geonosian bug army and, the only group not plucked directly from the prequel trilogy, Trandoshan mercenaries. These all have their share of easy fodder (the basic federation droids especially are little more than target practice) as well as a variety of overwhelmingly strong enemies.If the game did not work as well as it does then the best strategy would be to have your squad hold its ground out of harm's way, go at it alone and have them come revive you if it doesn't work out, and it's a testament to the excellent work the developers put into making the squad mechanics worthwhile.Orders are given easily, point at a piece of cover and press the Order button to have a squad mate take cover behind it. Same goes with entering turrets, breaching doors, setting explosives, etc. etc..It's a simple system, but it works well and is easy enough to do in the middle of hectic combat situations, of which there are plenty.The plot doesn't really add anything to existing lore, but it does its job and all of your squad mates have their own distinctive personalities, voices and preferences (though the explosives expert is no faster at placing a charge than his brothers).As long as you keep in mind that this is a short game and that it will primarily stay away from the plot of the films then you're in for a great time, and I recommend this title.

It may be a significant limitation, but the system works as intended. All events are scripted, but you still need to continuously assess the situation and order your squad accordingly.Republic Commando may not reach early Halo levels with the AI, but it has nothing to be ashamed of. Just don’t expect your squad to win the game for you; team management is a very crucial point, especially in hold the line situations.The game didn’t age well from a technical standpoint; modern systems may have a bit of a problem running it properly. But when they do, you are offered one of the best Star Wars games to date to play with.

												Despite me not having many hours on here. I put countless hours on this years ago back on my original Xbox. This game (in my opinion) still holds up with modern day games. Unfortunately, there are few and far between squad-based games out there like this. The only ones that still carry on this tradition would be Rainbow Six and Ghost Recon for example (Singleplayer at least). Which we need more games like this, instead of these one man superpowered (yet normal) soldiers that can regenerate wounds after getting shot multiple times, and with unintelligent A.I. (that seem like that they're just for show, like a hindrance, rather than helping the player take care of hostiles) that stays back 10 feet behind while the player is on the other side of the map, blasting their way through enemy territory. We need less games like that, and more of this, if the FPS Genre wants to at least survive in someway. Definitely worth buying, that is, if you like to work as a team. If you can't handle that responsibility, then look somewhere else.Oh and this game actually has a challenge to it. Pretty rare nowadays in the FPS Genre.9.7/10 Would buy and play again.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2016
												 Star Wars: Republic Commando was a great experience for the most part, but it got fairly repetitive after a while. I got VERY tired of how many times I've had to breach a door or kill Droidekas and Super Battle Droids, and  It doesn't help how easy this game is. Anything one would consider "challenging" about it is how you run out of ammo in the midst of every other SBD/Droideka/Spider-Droid/Magna-Guard "Ambush". Because of the game's repetitive tendancies, the little length that the game has seems like less of an issue. The game does have it's moments though. For example, I personally found it fun mowing down Battle Droids and Geonosians every once in a while. The game's soundtrack was an enjoyable mix of music from the Prequel Trilogy, a bit of music from the Original Trilogy, and some original music written specifically for this game. Soundtrack aside, the graphics of this game compliment the feel of being in the Star Wars universe as well. Despite all the problems the game has, it still has that charm to it that many other Star Wars games have, so I definately reccomend it

content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												If you're looking into this game, you should really get it.It's a fantastic game, it has a pretty good story, unique weapons, and you play with your squad for most of the game.The biggest part of the game is your squad. They're really amazing, you've scorch, sev, and fixer. They all have their specialties, and it's not super noticeable, but they do better than the others in their area. (Scorch- demolitions, fixer-computers/slicing, sev- weapons expert{sniping, anti-armor posts, turrets, etc.}) They listen to your orders, you can set them to do different things. You can have one guy sniping, one guy disabling the droid dispenser and still have the last one fighting head on with you. You can have them on the full offensive, you can have them staying in formation, you can have them moving carefully, ready to blow ammo into anything that moves.Plus there's the Humour. Really there's some funny jokes in there. Gotta love scorch XDThere's a really unique weapon setup in the game, you can have 3 guns. There's your standardized pistol (infinite ammo, energy recharge), the standardized rifle (with sniping and explosives attachments), and then you can have a single enemy weapon. That could be anything an enemy drops, like a geonosian beam rifle (pretty much shoots a powerful beam of energy) or a trandoshan shotgun, or even a wookie bowcaster. There's also heavy weapons you can get, like the ACP Heavy Repeater or the Wookie Rocket Launcher. Personally, by the end of the game I really only used the pistol, and the rifle attachments if I really need to.It also has a fair ammount of extra fun one time kind of stuff. Most of them come as a surprise, so I don't really wanna spoil it for you.When you play, keep in mind how useful cover can really be. You have an energy shield, which recharges, and a pistol with infinite ammo. If you can find some good cover, you can use those two together and take out just about anything with relative ease.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												This is a very good Star Wars game, made back in the waning days when Lucasarts still cared about video games. You take control of a squad of republic clone troopers each with his own personality (my personal fave is Sev, the cold, silent, deadly sniper on a hunt for blood). The gameplay is short, unfortunately; I think the 14 hours for my playthrough that is listed here is because I either didn't know where to go many times or my file got lost and I had to start over for some reason. At any rate, this game is a must for any hardcore Star Wars fan and perhaps even people who don't care so much about Star Wars and just want some military squad-based action in a science-fiction setting. Gameplay-wise, this game is terrific. You fight your way through jungles, heavily-fortified enemy bases, desert-terrain, etc as you carry out your missions. You can choose, in many situations, to go head-on with the enemies or sic your bloodthirsty comrades on them with the press of a button. The music and sounds are top-notch as usual in Star Wars games. You will hear the familar firing of laser blasters and roaring of wookies, not to mention the authentic Star Wars music we all know and love from the movies. Cons: Game is short, but by today's standards of 8-10 hours, I would say it fits in nicely. Perhaps the AI is a bit boring with the repeated use of "hide behind rock, pop out and shoot, maybe toss a frag, hide again, repeat", but let's be honest, this is the formula for most games, sadly even today. Oh, almost forgot, if I remember correctly this game has what felt like a moderate cliffhanger at the end. This is a huge con because it leaves the story unfinished I feel. It doesn't take away too much from this great game, but it still sucks. Checking online I see that a sequel was planned and then canceled. However, in 2011 there appeared to be reports that a sequel is still in the works. We will have to wait and see.9/10

												Very linear, hardly any replayability, but I thought it was a fun ride. There are only three missions. But all of them are quite long. Finished it at almost exactly 10 hours. Fights were as much as a test of how well you issue orders as it is a test of your ability to shoot things. Though I found that it was really easy to just run and knife scores of enemies so long as there isn't a "heavy" thrown into the mix.The ending sequence was pretty anti-climactic. The endings for the first two missions were harder and more tense.

content:

												Absolutley loved this game when it was new, was so excited about it back then I baught my first ever new aftermarket Graphics/video Card in order to play it at the best settings and it was beautiful. So many years later and the game is still awesome. Although the online multiplayer comunity has died since then, the gameplay is still just as fun and the squad A.I. and simple commands are still one of the best I've come across. In adddition I came to really like the squadmates as their own characters with their little banter back and forth. However I do have to point out and easily over looked physics issue, as the "ragdoll bodies" was new back then, sometimes the dead enemy units shake/twitch/jiggle about one the ground for a bit. Personally I think it's funny looking, but it is noticeable and you might see it a few times throughout the game. Other than that, the game is pretty much flawless in terms of squad shooter gameplay and audio  This game deserves a good sequal, but unfortunately probably won't get one. Anyways I'd recomend this game if you enjoy shooters and anything Star Wars, if you're not a fan of either, then this game may not be for you.

content:
Posted: March 5, 2014
												After the Jedi Knight/Dark Forces series started focusing more on Lightsaber battles and Force powers (which was eventually expanded even further in the Force Unleashed games) it was refreshing to play a good ol'-fashioned, Star Wars shooter again. The use of Star Wars assets isn't exactly done with the most accurate attention to detail, as the design of the droids and other baddies look very little like their saga counterparts, and the weapons would look very out of place in Lucas' universe, but the gameplay and level design more than make up for it. This is a short-but-sweet, fun, squad-based shooter, which doesn't try to be too clever or reinvent the wheel.It's incredible there was never a follow-up, considering the success of the game and the subsequent success of the Clone Wars TV series (which even featured a cameo by the Republic Commando squad), but who knows, maybe one day...

content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
												Star Wars: Republic Commando is a tactical first-person shooter set in the Star Wars universe, developed by LucasArts and published by Activision and LucasArts in 2005. The game uses the Epic Games Unreal Engine.In Star Wars: Republic Commando you play as an elite Clone Commando accompanied by three other squad members through three main missions with submissions included. In the game you investigate hostile areas and search for enemy Intel. You are Delta RC-1138 (Boss, orange suit), the leader of Delta 38 who meet up with Delta RC-1262 (Scorch, yellow suit), Delta RC-1140 (Fixer, green suit) and Delta RC-1207 (Sev, red suit). These elite Clone commandos are created at the clone factories on Kamino. As a squad leader you can order your squad members to attack, defend a position or blow up blockades and each squad member has its own abilities. During your military operations you will find yourself at Geonosis (Rocky desert planet) where droids are manufactured, at the Republic Assault Ship (RAS) and at Kashyyyk (Wookie Forest/Swamps Planet).I highly enjoyed this game because tactical functions and of the HUD (Head Up Display) interface which is built inside the Helmet of your character. Also the weapon designs are well done, for instance the DC-17m Commando Rifle Model which is an adaptable rifle of the Galactic Republic. You can change parts of the gun while in battle and switch a modular sniper- or anti-armor grenade launcher attachment when you progress into the storyline. I also liked the hidden blade (Knuckle Plate Vibro Blade) which comes in handy when you are out of ammunition or just for dealing massive damage in close-combat. The voice acting is great and the interaction between squad members makes the game feel lively. I highly recommend this game to people who like the Star Wars Universe or tactical first-person Sci-Fi shooters with great gameplay, certainly when the game is on sale!

												This, in my personal opinon, is the best Star Wars game in the entire collection even to date. This game is rich in story, has great character build, and actually has a lot of content for a game that is going on 11 years old. I played this game when I was younger on the original Xbox console, and replaying it on my PC was amazing. I love this game and all its glory even to this date. content:
Posted: May 4, 2015
												Unlike a lot of people, I only thought this game was okay (I'm giving it a positive review, but only just). I also believe that a lot of this game's positive reviews are a result of nostalgia (or being a devout Star Wars fan) at its best. Now don't get me wrong, I'm a MASSIVE Star Wars fan, which is exactly why I'm being honest. The idea for the game was great, and parts of it are fun, but it could have been done much better. Killing Super Battle Droids was just too time consuming. Pumping clip after clip of ammo into them just got monotonous very quickly. I did however like the conclusion of the story and thought the music was great.The multiplayer is a different story altogether. It reminded of Halo, to an extent (especially when everyone is grabbing a rocket launcher) and had solid enough gameplay which makes it fun with a few friends.In short, if you want a great Star Wars shooter get Battlefront II with some mods, you won't regret. I would still however pick up this game if it was on sale for the right amount since it's about as solid as any other average FPS.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2016
												I love this. I finished the game twice long before having a steam account, just for clarification. As a diehard Star Wars fan, I've always loved the alternate takes on the universe. Sure, I love Jedis, lightsabers and stuff, but most of all I love how Luke is just a simple farmer, Han is a regular smuggler and there are so many ordinary characters and all of them interesting; and what interests me the most is - what's going on beside the stuff we know from the movies? Aaaaand there you go, play Republic Commando. It's Star Wars by all means but it also isn't. It's a great shooter and even without all the mods out there, it still stands tall these days. Looks good, plays great and the atmosphere of the brotherly love felt among the commandos despite all of them being so epic and tough is amazing. IMPORTANT NOTE: the game is difficult as hell and you'll die a lot. Meaning on the HARD difficulty.

content:
Posted: March 5, 2014
												After the Jedi Knight/Dark Forces series started focusing more on Lightsaber battles and Force powers (which was eventually expanded even further in the Force Unleashed games) it was refreshing to play a good ol'-fashioned, Star Wars shooter again. The use of Star Wars assets isn't exactly done with the most accurate attention to detail, as the design of the droids and other baddies look very little like their saga counterparts, and the weapons would look very out of place in Lucas' universe, but the gameplay and level design more than make up for it. This is a short-but-sweet, fun, squad-based shooter, which doesn't try to be too clever or reinvent the wheel.It's incredible there was never a follow-up, considering the success of the game and the subsequent success of the Clone Wars TV series (which even featured a cameo by the Republic Commando squad), but who knows, maybe one day...

content:
Posted: June 8, 2014
												Star Wars Republic Commando is a first-person shooter about four deadly commandos, the Delta squad, helping the Republic's war effort. You take direct control of the squad's leader, Boss, while he guides his comrades, Sev, Scorch and Fixer, through their missions against the separatists forces.The main beef of the game is indeed to issue orders to your squad (set a demolition charge here, destroy that specific target, ...) in order to advance in the levels. Thankfully your mates' AI is quite handy and won't give you any serious problems, aside from some rare instances (it's worth mentioning that you and your clones aren't friendly fire-proof and your comrades have an annoying tendency to lock themselves into place if facing a mine field). The members of delta Squad can even revive each other if put down, which is rather fortunate.You can access a wide array of weapons (an assault and a sniper rifle, a bazooka of some kind, a pistol, ...) in order to battle several rather challenging enemies. The opponents in Republic Commando are indeed very hard to defeat and range from suicidal infantry units with little sense of survival to very sturdy and hard-hitting mini-bosses who can dish out a lot of damage towards your squad. You don't get to face any real boss, though.Republic Commando's rather short lenght is a well-known fact: it clocks around six or seven hours of gameplay. Many players tend to overlook this in favor of the game's great atmosphere, good soundtrack and solid gameplay, on top of providing a videogame about Star Wars without the usual Jedi and the Force angle and packed with a more gritty and edgier concept

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 22, 2015
												Star Wars: Republic Commando is quite possibly the most fun game I have ever played...no exaggeration.Republic Commando is a FPS that was released back in 2005 but stills holds up today as an extremely fun game. In the game, you play as RC-1138, AKA 'Boss', who is the...well...BOSS of an elite clone commando squad known as Delta Squad. You have 3 squadmates: Scorch, the munitions expert, Fixer, the computer slicer, and Sev, the sniper. The 4 of you go on many, many missions across the galaxy and basically destroy everyone in your path. The mechanics of the game are surprisingly smooth and it's easy to get the hang of. You know how to aim at things? You're all good. This game is so worth it for the price not only because of how fun it is, but because of the length of the campaign. I think we've all bought a game and had fun with it but were left short-handed because of how small the campaign was. No worrying about that with this game. You get a blaster rifle, a sniper, shotgun, pistol, grenades, and even a grenade launcher to blow your enemies to hell all while your squad mates are bantering with each other...which is probably one of the best parts of the game.TL;DR Here is a pros and cons listPROS-Good amount of content-Smooth mechanics-Squad banter-Good graphics for its release date-No extra BS. You shoot things.CONS-There isn't a sequel.......YET.(I don't have much play time on Steam at all because I mostly played it on my CD version.)

content:
Posted: December 29, 2015
												Star Wars Republic Commando tells the story of The Clone Wars by the point of view of the leader of a elite commando squad from the Republic fighting against the army of droids and mercenaries of the Separatists. With you there are three other commandos that you give orders in field during each mission,such as slicing door,planting detonators etc. The graphics are nothing to boost about,they are what 2005 games looked like in the day,but the music is great seeing as it triggers only in the right moments. The gameplay is pretty satisfaying and it really makes this game the best FPS i ever played.  The only thing i didn't like about this game is how it has a range of 8-10 hours of campaign,which is pretty short. Even more if you consider that the game ends abruptly AND with a cliffhanger,with a sequel that may never be made.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2015
												Star Wars Republic Commando is an fps game released in the star wars universe in 2005. In 2015 it still remains one of the best Star War games ever to be created and im trully sad to admit, i didnt appreciate it in its time of release. Back at the time i felt the game was really hard even on normal and i couldnt get accustomised with the various game mechanics. Now that im a bit older (but certaintly not wiser ^^), i came to appreciate this awesome title in all its grandeur.In this game you play the leader of a republic commando team, whose purpose is espionage,sabotage and advanced reconnaisssance. Obviously stealth is out of the question for like 95% of the game but the rest are yours for the making. Your team includes 3 more members each specializing in its own field. You get your sniper, your demo man and your enginneer as well. Throughout the game you are called to make tactical decisions and place your team8s around the field, in order to maximize your chances of survival and win your confrontations. Its sounds easy to do and at first it is, but as the game evolves your desicions must evolve as well.  All and all that was one aspect i enjoyed the most in this game. As with any good fps, you get to use a lot of different weapons and grenades and you can further enchance your own weapons to meet any kind of enemy. From the simple laser pistol to a full rocket launcher, this game has it all and more.In terms of gameplay difficulty, the game is not as hard as you might think, but its harder that most of todays standard measures. You dont get to do rambo stuff, cause you will be facing the ground and w8 for your m8s to revive you and that is really nervebreaking. All the levels have a linear design as well, so you wont miss your next objective. Maybe for most that is considered a down, but i think it works pretty well for this game.The graphics arent on par with todays standards, but you can modify the texture pack anyway you like and you can increase the games resolution as well. On the plus side even if you dont it still looks ♥♥♥♥ing awesome. And as with any star wars game that respects itself, the audio is one of the best things in this game. Everything from the tiniest footstep to the biggest blast has been exceptional and thats something i cant say for most games these days.The dialogues are grimm and funny at the same time and the voices seem to match everyone and everything in this game.All and all i recommend this game to everyone. If you are a fan of fps you will love it, if you are a fan of star wars you will love it even more and even if you dont like fps try it. You will love it too!!!

content:
Posted: December 14, 2014
												Although at first glance this game seems like it is a waste of any money at all, especially coming out near the attack of the clone game, it is one of the best star wars games I have played. This is my second favorite star wars shooter, barley falling below BattleFront 2. The Story is amazing, the atmosphere makes you feel like a badass, while at the same time feeling so weak and fragile. (Especially when fighting Super Battle Droids) This game is a must with either friends or being alone, as the AI will follow orders and even in today's standards are smart and think well. The HUD idea is great, it gives the look as if you are the clone itself. The graphics hold well, and the combat is spectacular. After playing this, you will have a craving for a sequel, and want to have a higher standard in today's shooter games. 10 out of 10. I enjoyed getting this game while being on sale.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 11, 2015
												This game is fantastic in almost everyway, particular emphasis on ALMOST, as there is one particular part about it that you should consider before getting this game.But before I do that, let us discuss what is great about this game, which is a lot. For starters, the gameplay in general is nothing short of amazing and gritty. The gunplay between the various different types of weapons (really attachments to one gun that all do different stuff but w/e) is satisfying. Most battles are often ripe with tension thanks to the more or less competant AI. The game also has a squad system. Wherever you go, you have about three other clones with you to help you out in battle. Like the enemy AI, they can hold their own fine. I especially like how they sometimes go into weird fighting animations with other enemies that they never lose. You can command these troopers to do certain stuff, like blow open doors, hack open doors, take up sniping positions, heal themselves, etc. This provides some level of strategy, though it's usually obvious what you want to do when you do it due to conveinient placement. Now, if any of your members (including yourself) ends up biting the dust, then you or another member can help them back up. Overall, the system works well enough, and  I reccommend you learn it fast.Normally, something like this would be good, but the game continues to impress with its characters and story. Just in case none of you know, this game takes place throughout the Clone Wars of the Prequel Films. It centers on Delta Squad, a four-man squad of elite clone troopers, who are genetically modified soldiers. Essentially ten-year trained badasses. However, the different types of personalities between the four all make sense. Boss, the clone you play as, is more or less uptight, but compassionate and caring for his men. Fixer is by-the-book, standard soldier guy. Sev is dark and overall creepy, but you grow to love the guy due to his wisecracking remarks with his fellow squadmates as well as his ruthless combat skills. Finally, there's Scorch, who is hilarious in every way. Throughout the story, you grow to care about them and what they go through, something you wouldn't normally expect from a game focusing on emotionless military badasses.The story itself is grand, if short (clocks in around 6-7 hours at most.) You get lead through planets like Kashyyk, an abandoned ship, and Geonosis.Overall, the game is amazing... except for one thing.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------This game is unstable as hell. I don't know what it is, but there is a possibilty your game will crash as soon as you make a new game and play the first mission. And when I say that, I mean as your guy literally lands on the ♥♥♥♥ing ground. Fixes have been made for this, but they don't work for me. So take that into consideration.9/10

												Star Wars: Republic CommandoThis is a Star Wars FPS that puts you in control of a squad of elite clones, better known as Delta Squad. Your squad members have different personalities. Funny, reckless, and serious. You have to complete campaigns, which can take quite a long time to complete. Your squad members have different abilities, one's good at explosives, one's good at computers, and one's good at sniping. You can assign them to do things. The shooting is like CoD, but the graphics are a bit outdated. I'd recommend this game, it's a good Star Wars FPS  game - possibly one of the best made. 9.5/10

content:
Posted: July 26, 2013
												Star Wars Republic Commando, Knights of the Old Republic, and Battlefront 1 are considered the Holy Trinity of Star Wars games.  You can put Rogue Squadron in there as well, but these three are always the ones everyone always talks about.  Republic Commando is an FPS set during the period of the Clone Wars where you command an elite clone unit called Delta Squad.  As you travel throughout the galaxy and undergo missions you will be faced with very difficult challenges, very immersive gameplay, and a cast of characters you will never forget.  This is a no-♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t game.  It's hard, it's fun, and it leaves you begging for more.  I remember this game came out during the time of Halo 1 and after playing both I thought Republic Commando just kicked way much more♥♥♥♥♥  This is a game you must play if you're a Star Wars fan or an FPS fan.  You will be hooked right as soon as you give your squad that first "BREACH THAT DOOR" command.I'm giving this game a strong 9.5/10.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												One of the most fun and challenging Star Wars games to date.  Don't bother reading the negative reviews, they're all just Call Of Duty fanboys expecting a Star Wars version of their favorite game, which it is not. This game actually requires you to try and to think, not just run around  one shotting every enemy you see while you take a thousand hits and not die. Enemies take time to kill, and some require teamwork to take down. The characters are pretty awesome and as the game progresses, it gets more challenging and more interesting. It's always fun to stab a B1 Battle Droid and see its insides splatter on your hud, then see your teammate tackle a Droideka and smash its head in. Even seeing another teammate snap a Geonosians head. It's just an incredible game. Anybody who says otherwise, is an idiot and has no taste in games whatsoever. Buy this game.You think this is a joke?   Buy it already.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2015
												Star Wars Republic Commando (or as I like to call it also, Band of Clone Bros) is the forgotten and underrated Star Wars video game that everybody that loves the Star Wars franchise should play. The story of the game is based on the 2nd and 3rd movies of the prequel trilogy, where you play as the leader of a Spec Ops squad of 4 Clones of the Galactic Republic who are responsible for performing special missions that occure behind the scenes of the Clone Wars. This is a squad based game, where using your squad team seriously will be your road for victory. The fact that you play as a Clone, fighting along aside with a team of other Clones, breaks the monotony of the usual protagonists of a story of a Star Wars game, which tend to be Jedis, Siths or some random bounty hunter.I agree, like the vast majority of people who played it, that this is a good game - but not a perfect one. It has one problem that I felt frustrated about: while the enemy was agressive against you, your squad team will be very weak and will lack agressivness, unless you babysit them all the time. Sometimes, they will just get close to an enemy and try killing them by melee (it reminds me of the Warscape Engine BS that is now plaguing the Total War series...), instead of trying to get to cover by their own initiative. Another problem  that I have with the game is the lack of variety with the level designs: the game is divided only by 3 chapters, which are limited equally to 3 areas (first you fight in one planet, then inside a ship, and then again in another planet). A little bit of more effort from the producers of this videogame could have created more variety for you to be present in another scenarios/planets of the Clone Wars. But I believe this problem to be minor, when you compare to the much more positive aspects of the game.Still, I cannot recommend you buy it at full price (except if your are a Star Wars nerd :P), since it is an old game and it no longer has an active multiplayermode. Buy it only when it´s in promotion.Like many people claim, this game really needs a sequel - where you play as the same squad team, now part of the forces of the eeeeeeeevil Galactic Empire. It would have been a much better sequel to make instead of the disaster that was Star Wars "BattleFront" EA (THE GAME IS NOT WORTH OF DESERVING OF "BATTELFRONT" ON IT´S TITLE!!!). Unfortunatelly, this game appears to have been forgotten and I don´t think a sequel (or a reboot) will ever be created.7.5 out of 10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 15, 2014
												Gritty, dark, and a heck of a lot of fun to play, Star Wars: Republic Commando is a first person tactial shooter that finds the perfect balance between strategy and action.Whereas most First-Person shooters take the action route there are still a few extreme tactical and strategy based military such as the Tom Clancy: Rainbow Six series. The Rainbow Six series takes a linear strategy and tactical based approach to military operations. The game focuses on the "How to" rather than the "What to." The problem with games like this is that they combine the complex strategy with a genre that most people prefer to stay focused on the "What to." First-Person Shooters. Therefore creating an issue. You have those who love it because it of it strict strategy focus and then you have those who hate it because it doesn't have enough action. Republic Commando solves this issue...It blends (and balances) the action with the strategy. Featuring a one key strategy system you can command your squad members directly and quickly. No sub-menus, no complicated explanation. Just push and play. One of the games main features is a excellent AI system. And boy is it good...You squad members know how to fight and how to do it efficiently. They automatically take cover and stay focused on the objective. They eliminate the primary targets first and take on the secondary ones later. The first time playing the game through, I found myself dying more than the AI! Now that is good...The gameplay is fast paced, frantic, and exciting. It perfectly balances strategy and action.The graphics are...meh...In their day they were probably amazing. But now a dated Quake engine remains. Don't get me wrong the graphics aren't bad, but by today's standards they are a little old, but acceptable. The sound is good and the soundtrack is perfect. The soundtrack by Jesse Harlin is a great blend of dark overtones, action sequences, and excellent buildup. The sound effects in game sound exactly like Star Wars.The campaign is extremely fun. It isn't even much of a campaign. It is just three big missions broken up into small parts. I have probably played the game's through about 7 times. My only complaint about the campaign is the rather abrupt ending. Now I won't spoil anything but it will leave you feeling like..."WHAT! THAT'S IT! THAT WASN'T HOW IT WAS SUPPOSED TO END! THERE WAS SOOOOO MUCH BUILD UP! COME ON!"Then you will go frantically searching the web to try and find if there is a sequal. And you'll find this: CancelledAnd when your all done you can play the multiplayer! Which is fun, but pretty much dead...So in short this game is awesome. Go get it!Overall Rating: 7.5/10Presentation: 10/10Story: 8/10Gameplay: 7/10Graphics: 6.5/10Sound: 9/10Lasting Appeal: 7/10Overall Rating: 7.5/10Content Review:Star Wars: Republic Commando is a tough game to review in terms of content. While much of the game is dark, gritty, and permeated by death, on has tot take int the account the fact that...well...it's Star Wars. This is (so far) the most violent Star Wars Video Game to date. Thankfully, violence is the only category that scores high in this game, in terms of content.Positive Elements: You fight on the good side. You stand for morals such as teamwork, unity, and justice. Teamwork is essential to success in the game.6/10 (Moderate) Violence: The game is a First Person Shooter, so some violence is expected. What is different about this game game though in comparison to previous Star Wars games is that it features an extensive amount of blood, gore, and corpses. The Genossian bug enemy's you fight break into bits and pieces when killed. If you shoot an enemy up close blood will splatter on your visor only to be removed by a wiper blade seconds later. When shooting at an enemy you can see spurts of blood flying off. Combat is highlighted by screams, cries of pain, and yelling. In addition to all that, many bodies of human clones are found scattered throughout the game.3/10 (Infrequent/Mild) Language: D--n and Hell are used occasionally. Insults like, clankers, and scumbag are uttered with frequency.0/10 (None) Sexual Content: :)0/10 (None) Drugs/Alcohol: :)4/10 (Present) Negative Elements: Death permeates the environment. Much of the game is dark and has a bleak outlook on things. Frequently the Commandos quote from their fake rule book which says things like "Rule Number 1: Kill them before they kill you."Other Moral Issues: The weird mystical Force is mentioned (e.g."May the force be with you.") but never elaborated on. The Commandos are cloned from another human being, as are many of the other soldiers you see in game. Final Content Rating: 5.5 (Acceptable)Key Elements- Violent - Gritty and Dark- Death permeates the environment- Infrequent Mild Language

content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												STAR WARS: Republic Commando, a video game that takes place between Attack of the Clones and Revenge of the Sith, is an ideal example for a STAR WARS game about ordinary soldiers.  Fun, humorous, and unique, its pros outway its cons, but the problems can still pop up.Plot:You are Delta 38, the leader of a group of elite clone commandos working for the republic.  You, along with your team, must do the jobs that are too big to know about and too extreme for a regular clone.  Your team is the greatest weapon you have.  Versatile, yet disfunctional, your squad consist of 07 AKA Sev, a vicious hunter who rarely ever misses, 62 AKA Scorch, the demolitions expert with the maturity of a teenager, and 40 AKA Fixer, your second-in-command and tech head who is serious, yet pure of heart.  They will either cheer for you or jeer at you.  Nevertheless, you four are family, and that's how it will always be.PROS: - Good characters you can invest in- Spectacular wepons- The squad moves and operates like real life soldiers- Very funny catchphrases and jeers- Unique locations- Distinctive weapons- Extras are interestingCONS:- Not a lot of locations- Gameplay takes some getting use to- No controller functionality

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2016
												I remember the first time I put that disk, that artwork of Delta Squad giving me excitement, waiting for this game to finish installing so I could play as a Clone Commando. I was 15, perhaps, maybe 14. Being a Star Wars fan, spending hours playing Knights of the Old Republic, Jedi Outcast and Jedi Academy.Got this on a discount a while ago, wanted to have my old games on Steam. - and still, this feels so damn good.Nostalgia isn't a reason to still hype over this game. Republic Commando did define the First Person Shooter genre, combining a Squad-based Gameplay with a Tactical Shooter. You play your cards right, you don't die. Still, many shooters can't reach this level, they can't make a fast gameplay combined with team management in the middle of the combat. This game gave us a choice to place our commandos in the right places, managing our resources between having more firepower and getting the job done. Not the best variety of weapons, sure; still leading a group of four in various scenarios is enough to get yourself in a challange.If anything, it's worth playing for the story itself. Being a "Deluxe Model" in a Clone Army, leading a squad of Clone Commandos with different characteristics. Listening to them trashing at each other, commenting on kills and reacting to your actions. Well-designed, well-thought.To this day, Republic Commando is still one of the most feature-rich First Person Shooters out there. Still looking good, still has a damn-good story, still enojyable, still challanging. - Do you like First Person Shooters? Then, this is a must have.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
												A not so long time ago in a country not far far away came a game so good we would ask for a sequel for ten years after release and still has not got one yet. This is star wars Republic Commandos. In the introduction you are shown the early years of a clone through quick clips of training introducing your squad. Your excellently written and acted squad is comprised of Fixer, the hacker and technical expert, Sev who is the hunter and sniper of the group who jokes around with Scorch, the demolitions expert who is always telling jokes at the worst of times. You and your squad fight on iconic planets from the movies such as Geonosis and Kashyyyk doing missons such as killing geonosian leaders, blowing up droid factories and saving wookie generals. The game is a first person shooter (obviously) with some strategy elements involved via squad commands such as ordering your troops to move to tactical positions, provide covering fire, attack targeted enemies and seize objectives. Certain actions will play to a commando's strengths like Sev is the best with a sniper and Scorch arms explosives faster and Fixer hacks quicker. This game looks good even though it came out about a decade ago and has really nice level design. The campaign is short lasting about 5-7 hours but it makes you eager for more and the story set up a sequel which we unfortunately never got but i hope that one day we will. All in all i give this game an 8/10, i would have rated if the campaign was slightly longer.

content:
Posted: September 11, 2015
												This game is fantastic in almost everyway, particular emphasis on ALMOST, as there is one particular part about it that you should consider before getting this game.But before I do that, let us discuss what is great about this game, which is a lot. For starters, the gameplay in general is nothing short of amazing and gritty. The gunplay between the various different types of weapons (really attachments to one gun that all do different stuff but w/e) is satisfying. Most battles are often ripe with tension thanks to the more or less competant AI. The game also has a squad system. Wherever you go, you have about three other clones with you to help you out in battle. Like the enemy AI, they can hold their own fine. I especially like how they sometimes go into weird fighting animations with other enemies that they never lose. You can command these troopers to do certain stuff, like blow open doors, hack open doors, take up sniping positions, heal themselves, etc. This provides some level of strategy, though it's usually obvious what you want to do when you do it due to conveinient placement. Now, if any of your members (including yourself) ends up biting the dust, then you or another member can help them back up. Overall, the system works well enough, and  I reccommend you learn it fast.Normally, something like this would be good, but the game continues to impress with its characters and story. Just in case none of you know, this game takes place throughout the Clone Wars of the Prequel Films. It centers on Delta Squad, a four-man squad of elite clone troopers, who are genetically modified soldiers. Essentially ten-year trained badasses. However, the different types of personalities between the four all make sense. Boss, the clone you play as, is more or less uptight, but compassionate and caring for his men. Fixer is by-the-book, standard soldier guy. Sev is dark and overall creepy, but you grow to love the guy due to his wisecracking remarks with his fellow squadmates as well as his ruthless combat skills. Finally, there's Scorch, who is hilarious in every way. Throughout the story, you grow to care about them and what they go through, something you wouldn't normally expect from a game focusing on emotionless military badasses.The story itself is grand, if short (clocks in around 6-7 hours at most.) You get lead through planets like Kashyyk, an abandoned ship, and Geonosis.Overall, the game is amazing... except for one thing.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------This game is unstable as hell. I don't know what it is, but there is a possibilty your game will crash as soon as you make a new game and play the first mission. And when I say that, I mean as your guy literally lands on the ♥♥♥♥ing ground. Fixes have been made for this, but they don't work for me. So take that into consideration.9/10

content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												One of the few good things to come out of the Prequel Era.The gameplay revolves around properly managing your squad, and has interesting encounters. The scope is more focused than other, grand and epic Star Wars games, but by the end of the game, you've really connected with your squad. They may all be numbers to the Jedi, but you will remember each character's colour, number, nickname, and preferences.The only unfortunate thing is that the game's premise could have easily made this a 4-player-co-op shooter, but it isn't. The multiplayer is generic and mostly bland, but the single player campaign is definitely worth it. The least enjoyable parts of the game are when you are separated from your squad, working independently. Without the squad management, it becomes a generic shooter set in the Star Wars universe.

The controls are still fun after all of these years (11 years later) and the graphics are well worth it too since you can pick this game up for less than $5 when it goes on sale. The campaign mode is pretty short but it's pretty challanging at times. There are a few glitches in this game though which only increases the difficulty. The glitches are all with your teammates though. The AI is challenging and your squad works their butt off too. I haven't attempted to play the multi-player but the campaign alone is worth the time.Best Star Wars game to immerse you in the universe since there's a lot more in this world than Jedi and the force.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2016
												A great game for fans of simple, FPS shooters, but it is also a relatively hollow game, all things considered. -The gameplay is fun, and the ability to command your squad is a unique gameplay mechanic. -There are no upgrades, collectibles, or unlockables, and the levels are fairly linear. This can be good, bad, or a little of both, depending on your personal preference.-The story is minimal, but definitely there. The characters are likeable, but relatively static, and the narrative is pretty surface level. The ending is very sudden, and doesn't really give the player much resolution.-The game is very stable, with very few bugs, but the few bugs that can occur were, at least in my experience, very noticeable, though not game-breaking.-The game can be very nostalgic for fans of shooters from the mid 2000s (arguably the peak of shooter games), and the story may be quite interesting for Star Wars fans (I believe this game is still canon, in case you were wondering).-There is virtually no replayability, but considering the current price for this game, the 9-12 hours of gameply you'll get are well worth what you'll pay.-The graphics aren't bad at all, especially for its time.Overall review = 6/10 Not great, but for $9.99, certainly not bad

content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
												Ah, I love this game. I remember playing it when it was on the X-box, and was is great to play it again.It's a squad based action shooter, with rather intelligent AI companions (Although they can't use any weapons other than the main gun unless in special cover). You play through the game taking place during the Clone wars as a elite squad sent on special missions, and in my opinion it really nails that atmosphere of taking on the impossible odds, as your sent against increasingly difficult hoards of enemies. Keep it mind, it isn't an RPG, there are no real choices or decisions to be made, and there is no multiplayer scene, giving it unfortunately very little replayability other than for enjoyment. It is a fun game however, and offers some of what I feel is the best squad gameplay and teamwork mechanics even compared to newer games today. Worth picking up if you just want to shoot some baddies and lead a commando team.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 1, 2014
												This game feels like it should have been made in the 90s, when memorable characters and good stories came to games without question.It's an FPS where you lead a squad of clone soldiers - all who manage to have a distinct and enjoyable personality - as you tear around behind the curtains of the Star Wars universe.  You won't jumping from any rooftops in flashy lightsaber fights, but your crack team of mighty mortals finds their own way to be awesome.Squad controls are simple, too.  It reminds me of a more involved Mass Effect.  You can give general orders like fall back or take cover, but all throughout the level are little hot spots that a squade mate (or yourself) can take advantage of.  Lot of enemies in a room?  Get someone on the turret.  Just make sure you cover him on the way over there so he doesn't get shot (or you do it, and have your guys cover you).It's a surprisingly great game with a fun concept, delightful characters, and solid mechanics.  It's aged, but not so much that it's not worth $20.

Posted: March 28, 2015
												I wish there was a star rating for steam, because while Republic Commando is a good game, it has a lot of problems. Its singleplayer campaign is just too short, bordering the length of the original portal, and the finish is anticlimactic. You just start to connect with your AI squadmates when the campagin ends, and its kind of frustrating that they couldn't have added on another mission or two. On the positive side its a fun game with a lot of strategy and a decent enough plot, but I'd wait until it goes on sale before buying it. I also really enjoyed the mechanics for working with your AI squad mates, and I wish more FPSes did AI interaction as well as this title. All in all a good game, but with dated graphics and thats just too short.
